Would recommend if you got it on sale. It is very much a 'create your own fun' sort of game, rather than having definite goal. However, it feels more like a well polished demo than a full release, and seems to completely overestimate its depth (particularly in Story Mode). The genetics system is quite basic, and you can see every gene your creatures have (unless you're in sandbox and disable it). Mutations are based solely on player input rather than occurring naturally. For a game in which the physical traits of the creatures is the main focus, the creature models are quite underwhelming, even considering the graphical style of the game. If this game had mod support or still received updates I think it would be much easier to recommend it at full price, but it has neither of those things.

Story Mode
Story mode is intended to be a sort of tutorial for new players. The (unskippable) tutorial does a good job of explaining the game, but really didn't need a whole game mode for it. This game mode has several genetic mutations unique to it (I *think* you can get the same genes in sandbox, just not as mutations). Which is a bit of an issue if you want to complete everything in a sandbox world. There are two main goals: get home, and keep a certain gene in your creatures the whole while. The game does not explain how to get home, and it does not point out the unique gene or its significance. I believe the intended way to play is to move to each new island, completely conquer it while adapting your creatures to it, and then move on to do the same to the next island (which you've probably chosen at random). If you choose to play that way, even if you know the fastest path home, don't die and restart, don't lose the special gene and restart - you're going to be spending many hours playing this way. Far too many for what this game has to offer. And you *are* going to die, and you *are* going to lose the gene, potentially *many* hours in to a run. And once you 'win', you get to keep doing what you've been doing this entire time, minus the stress of the special gene. There is also zero customization to this game mode's settings unless you want to use console commands.

Sandbox Mode
Sandbox Mode really illustrates the lack of features and depth of the features the game does have. You can customize what type of island you start on, the genes of your starting creatures, their lifespans, and the resources/animals that spawn. Most of these are an on/off switch, or a slider with a too limited range. A win condition can be set, but your options are very limited. Despite being the 'main' game mode, you are unable to get several mutations (locked behind story mode). Meaning you need to find outsider creatures that have those genes (if that is possible, I'm not sure), and invite them to your tribe. If you wanted to 100% the mutations menu, you're going to have to play Story Mode. I mentioned above that this is a 'make your own fun' game, but Sandbox really doesn't give you the options to make your world just as you want it.

Applying to both of the gamemodes 
It just gets repetitive and boring. Pick food, cut grass, breed, maybe move to another island that may or may not be mostly indistinguishable, die, repeat. And very little other than the breeding is interesting. Even that is shallow - choose two creatures with the traits you want, and if you don't want the baby, drown it. The genetics and mutation menus look a lot more complicated that they really are. As for food: gathering from anything is about the same. It's all about what your creature can gather, not its diet. Hunting is time-consuming and just not worth it unless you have extra creatures with good attack. Predators are dangerous, but you can just run away (or hide, if you clicked the appropriate colors and patterns in the mutation menu and got it to pass down). Moving to another island is risky, and often leads to undesirable creatures staying by berry bushing and harvesting them while everyone else travels. This gets old very quickly. The islands are also pretty bland. Other than a few different creatures and plants, they're mostly the same. Sometimes almost identical. 

Another review said this as well, but: Look at the screenshots. That's what you're playing. That's not a part of the game, that's pretty much all of it. What you see is what you get.

Despite all I've said above, I had some fun with it. I might go back to it in the future, but I doubt my thoughts will change on it. The creatures are interesting and cute, and while the gameplay isn't too complex, it can be punishing if you are unaware of the dangers, take too many risks, or are just unprepared. I haven't run into any bugs, and the game runs smoothly. Once you've figured out the interface, it's quite easy to use. Just get it on sale if you can wait. | Jogo Ã³timo para passar o tempo.  [/spoiler] | Bad writing, music, and flat characters. 
Also to me it feels so wrong to fall in love with your pets....

THIS IS NOT A CORN GAME.

Sweet, simple, cheesy read and I'm eating it all up. Considerably more polished than Kikuya as to the writing & dialogue. However, [b] THE LACK OF CGs ARE A CRIME [/b] (Only 3 to 4...? per route).

I love that the MC is not a doormat, she's considerably bratty at times [spoiler] &  i love the business minded aspect though shallowly put at times [/spoiler]  and her personality differs with each route as opposed to Kikuya's Mary Sue MC that just drives the immersion away.

Anyways, for route recommendations:

Asagiri's route tackles the dynamics of Yoshiwara and the Mc's feelings quite well 

[spoiler] as he basically whores himself out to help MC's family, and MC struggles with seeing her beloved be pimped out [/spoiler].

Props to Asagiri for knowing what he wants, who he is, and being more of a fleshed out character tbh, very refreshing. Also, [spoiler] very steamy route [/spoiler]


Moving forward, Ageha's route is absolutely adorable first romance type of stuff, it felt pure despite the suggestive CGs, which by the way are top tier, Ageha's CGs beat Asagiri's imho. Felt like watching a cute puppy love turned into more.

To end though, one last complaint, or two: IT IS A CRIME THAT MUSASHI DOESNT HAVE A ROUTE, I HAVE A BONE TO PICK WITH WHOEVER MADE THAT DECISION, also, maybe just me idk, but Utsusemi's sprite could have been improved upon :/ . | In 2024, understanding men feels harder than ever. Their tangled emotions and confusing thoughts make it exhausting to respond in a meaningful way. My mind wich is constantly overthinking and trying to make sense of everything, is just burned out.

Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™ve decided to simplify things. Like in technical drawing, Iâ€™ll start with the basicsâ€”studying â€œ2D menâ€ to figure out how their minds work. Once Iâ€™ve got that down, I think Iâ€™ll be able to understand â€œ3D men.â€ more better.

Ironically enough a girl I have a crush on suggested I play this and between my own relationship troubles and bouts of depression this game really spoke to me, this story is truly beautiful and made me cry multiple times.

I'm not a big visual novel girl but this game touched something in me and it changed my perspective on things, it helped me find beauty in a world that seems so meaningless and through my sadness this silly little game about two idiots falling in love just spoke to me on a level that very few stories have ever done before.

Even while typing this i'm crying, it's such a dumb silly little thing but I found this story at the exact time I needed to find it.

This is probably my favorite visual novel I've ever read :) | éå¸¸æœ‰è¶£å’Œç”œç”œçš„å…¬è·¯ç‰‡

This was a very surprising VN. â€œLove in the Glenâ€ is about an interior designer called â€œZoe Richardsonâ€, who the player controls. Like most visual novels, you go through the story making choices and decisions for her and then watch her destiny unfold in front of your very eyes. In that sense there is nothing new and itâ€™s what youâ€™d expect from a Visual Novel. Not that thatâ€™s a bad thing, if you buy a chocolate cake you do expect it to taste like chocolate, do you not?

The surprising thing about it is the storyline. It really doesnâ€™t feel very anime at all. Which does come as a surprise as one does expect a VN to somewhat have an anime feel (remember my chocolate cake reference? Well that applies here too). That being said, itâ€™s not a bad story, the writing is actually pretty damn good. Granted there are some odd moments where you get a surprisingly short storyline, if you embark on one of the long ones youâ€™ll definitely get your moneyâ€™s worth. Especially if youâ€™re like me and have already read many VNâ€™s and are looking for something different. If you havenâ€™t ever played a VN before then I wouldnâ€™t recommend this game as it is in so many ways not like other VNâ€™s and you might get the wrong impression of the genre.

Other aspects of the VN were rather good too. I liked the cute little mini game and the music was always very nice and fitted the mood really well. Of course it had itâ€™s weak points too, there are no game settings and there are some bits in the story that felt a bit odd.

All in all a good VN with an entertaining story! Chocolate cake!

TL;DR A good all-round VN but rather different to most. I wouldnâ€™t recommend this to someone as his or her first Visual Novel, but for anyone who happens to like them, this is a must-have. | + Liked the inclusion of the match 3 mini-game (though what it has to do with interior design really is a mystery)
+ Unusual setting for a VN
+ I liked the inclusion of a f/f route
+ Variety of characters with unique backgrounds

- Very short (I completed all endings in 57 minutes and the rest of the playtime is idling for cards)
- Boring story (you don't really do much aside from go out to eat and go to work)
- Characters don't really seem different to each other voice-wise and you don't actually get to interact with them much
- There's one part that plays a lengthy audio clip of spoken dialogue with no subtitles | Pros:

- Good writing

- Many endings

Overall I liked the writing but I really didn't like how half-baked the story felt. However it's an indie game and the base price is not too steep and I believe I shouldn't judge it too harshly. So it's a recommendation bearing in mind its shortness. Buy it on sale. | A good improvement compared to the previous titles released by these developers. The art style is simple, and the only thing that bothered me was the lack of expressions on the characters (they usually have all the same face, sometimes it might change just a bit). But thatâ€™s a pet peeve of mine, maybe other people wonâ€™t see this as a flaw. 

The soundtrack is really good. It was what made me buy this game at first!

Also, this is probably the longest game by these devs. It didnâ€™t felt rushed, the routes were more elaborated and the characters were more likable. Get it on a good sale!

5/10.

This is the sequel to AdVenture Capitalist, but with a communist twist and completely different interface. The game is a clickcer resource collection game with a nice retro 1950s era look to it. All tho the game is in early access it still plays well and has balanced resources. There are in game purchases to move along quicker but they are not compulsary and you can still advance without them. The dev's seem to take note of the feedback they are given and do regular updates.

Overall an enjoyable game for the clicker genre. | O irmÃ£o russo mais novo do AdVenture Capitalist que nÃ£o deu muito certo!!

There have been numerous, helpful research trial and experiment improvements added, which aid progression even further. The only downside I can think of is that scientists may be a little too easy to stockpile. You only need to 5 to activate the Comrade x7777 trial, which is one of the main reasons why progression has improved. I would either slim down a few achievement scientist awards, or make the x7777 trial a bit more costly. Aside from that, it's gotten a lot better.

Before I get in to this review as I'm well aware that I am needlessly wordy when writing reviews I'll give you the tl;dr here. I do like this game but it ultimately falls short due to feeling unfair at times. I'm still counting it as recommended as It's no real strain on your wallet and is really fun in small doses, but it's very repetitive and may be annoying. 

Okay now I yap. 

As someone who is fairly unfamiliar with the roguelike genre as a whole, I'm not going to sit here and pretend like I know anything about game balance or really any of the kind of things that make this sort of game tick, but I *will* bounce off of what I have seen other people say as it does line up with my personal experience. 

This game has a lot of good things going for it. The art style is cute and cartoony, the music (what little of it there is) is pleasant, the small animations look nice, the little blurbs of banjo kazooie style speech from the enemies isn't too insufferable and the game as a whole is very easy to pick up and get in to without too much of a learning curve, if any at all. If you're familiar with how to play solitaire in any capacity, you'll understand how this game works. 

The problems start arising with the balance of the encounters. Now, as I said, I know little to nothing about what makes these sort of games work in terms or really anything, but I do have vague ideas about it and I know how the fights feel to me; and that is incredibly unbalanced most of the time. Even on the standard difficulty i find myself getting stuck 3 or 4 fights in most of the time due to not having enough resources to defend myself with. 

Now, I am very aware that perhaps that's just me, maybe I'm just bad at the game, but again, using the insight other reviews have provided I'm inclined to think that at least partially it is not me and that there are some issues with encounter balance. 

I do really love this game, but I find myself either getting sucked in to a loop of getting a few fights in and continually trying with no real progress made or I just end up getting frustrated and quitting out, and honestly that isn't a really pleasant experience. I don't regret purchasing this game, as I do play it frequently, but I am still a little disappointed by it.

I'm a big, big fan of tower defense games and well, it's not always easy to make new games in this genres for many reasons; the most common ones are that virtually all the tower defense games available from Flash websites and all over the stores are made by indie developer studios or single developers, and many of them (like the Kingdom Rush series, Incursion, Gemcraft, Curse Treasure, Protector.. it's full of awesome series :P) deal with similar mechanisms and settings. 
Of course, this is a little bit "forced"; what I'm trying to say is that these games have to follow a precise scheme made up by one or more paths that the enemies will walk on (there can be multiple paths, or different layers so that enemies can climb ladders, or even circular paths like in Protector where before hitting your health points the enemies will "circle" for some rounds over the same path), there are somehow fixed spots for towers (some games give you more freedom of choice, but generally speaking you'd want to put the most effective towers obviously in the places that are more effective against the most enemies) and of course speaking of the towers (or, like in Incursion and Kingdom Rush, towers that spawn 3 different warriors, mages, archers etc.) we're almost every time revolving around similar concepts: archers, magical towers, warrior/tank towers, cannon towers all of them upgradable.
What a developer can do is to polish the graphics, to invent some kind of plot and to put all of his efforts on creating different, entertaining and new upgrades to the towers themselves, so that they will Idk, transform into mecha robots or that the warriors will become paladins or that towers can be built for 5 or 6 floors like in the awesome Giant and Dwarves game by the Labugames studio.
So, when you go outside lines traced by your ancestors (xD) you assume all the risks of creating something unenjoyable. I played dozens of tower defense games which tried to create new systems, like 3D sci-fi games or such, but they ultimately ended to be difficult to enjoy and very repetitive, like the developers had played all the classic games before and wanted at all costs to create a totally different game. Unfortunately, tower defense games are most effective when they're placed into a medieval/fantasy setting - of course speaking of fantasy you can add all the mages and the mech things you want, but my idea is that the simple "protect your kingdom" idea is the best one, or "protect your gems" if you look to Cursed Treasure or similar series, always set in a medieval fantasy setting.
This game, as the title says, makes use of a traditional medieval setting with a glimpse of charm by creating a 3D world - something that it's impossible to have on a Flash website, hence I sincerely recommend you to play this game full-screen 'cos even on a wide monitor it's difficult to see everything properly, trust me xD I always try everything windowed but this game needs to be played fullscreen and has no problems at all of crashing or freezing.
Three champaigns are available, and three difficulty settings too - starting from normal and not easy unfortunately, but it's ok ahah xD; every champaign (only the first will be available at the beginning) consists of 20 different levels set in a similar world.
Ok, sometimes you'll get hints of a storyline but yeah, I appreciate that the developers tried to give to the game a less casual outfit but it's nothing remarkable xD Anyways, you'll be always in a 3D setting which can be zoomed in and out and moved by dragging the mouse cursor and well, everything works pretty much as every other medieval-settled tower defense game.. and to me, for only 0,99â‚¬, it works greatly.
You have a fundamental fast forward button, your health points that get damaged if the enemies make to your base castle, the amount of money you can spend and on the upper right side the number of waves - nothing new, everything good :)
With hotkeys automatically assigned to numbers from 1 onwards, you'll have to put your selected towers on fixed squares all over the map; here you don't have fighters but just towers that of course will launch different projectiles - bolts, arrows, cannonballs, bullets and so on (overall, six different towers) - and you'll be able to upgrade them in order to increase range, damage, fire speed rate and so on. The WASD keys will prove to be extremely useful to navigate the maps, but the fast forward/pause system works nice and you have all your time to plan everything. And of course you'll have the usual spells: meteors, hammers from the sky, paralyzing roots and so on.
Plus, every tower is upgradable to different levels (some towers cap at 3, others at 5 and so on) and many levels will require some strategy and not putting the same tower everywhere and let the enemies come to you xD
Of course, you will have the chance to buy upgrades between levels: mainly spells as I said, but also upgrades for your in-game towers; you'll be able to carry on only four different magics on the playground :)
The game lacks something; hotkeys for spells, a button to send waves earlier, easier system to upgrade your towers, some more work in order to place better buttons like Start and so on, but really for an indie tower defense game coming out at 0,99â‚¬ I don't really get what we could expect more.
I get an objection I read somewhere: this games seems to be available for free on smartphones. Admitting that I don't play that much on phones, on one hand I don't really understand how such a 3D broad game like this can be correctly played on such a little screen but on the other hand I think that 1â‚¬, 0,5â‚¬ as it's now on sale or even less if you've got a coupon is not a big expense at all, considered that there are no DLCs or microtransactions in game - by buying the game you'll have everything and you'll just have to play, grind get money, upgrade your towers and face the difficult levels and bosses and so on.
Yes, it's a classic tower defense games and yes, it doesn't offer anything new but it's great to have games like this on Steam and even for a (very old and) long-time tower defense player like me it proved to be a solid title in its genre, not boring at all and worth to be played. Graphics are very nice, the gameplay offers a great difficulty curve and the six towers and all the other upgrades and magics you can buy make this title, in my opinion, a nice one in its genre. 
Of course I have always to add my two cents in the end: you need to like tower defense games, and you also have to know that there are dozens of better tower defense games than this one, sometimes much better. But this doesn't subtract anything to the value of this game - and I'm always the first to downvote a game not worth to be bought and played.
So, for a 1â‚¬ (at its highest non-sales price) game, this has lots of longevity and although it doesn't offer anything new, it's enjoyable for what concerns both gameplay, upgrading system and graphics; it's difficult but it's also very fast. I get the "boring"/"grindy" objections but well.. are there tower defense games that don't require grinding? Ahah :)
This is why I said that I'd not suggest this one for a tower defense beginner.. I'm going to write a review about this game looking at it more as a F2P FPS than a Ghost in the Shell game. Yes its in the title. Yes the character models and things are there and people are getting annoyed because its missing some key aspects of the series. 

But im going to cut that out and focus on the gameplay, mechanics and the pros and cons of it being currently in its Early Access state. Ive played going on 5 hours straight of matches while taking in the things I saw to help clear up any uncertainties people may have. (Be gentle its my first review and it's long)

Lets begin with the PROS that I found were good.

+Movement. It responds well. Decent running and movement animation. Even the action animations are solid. No bugs personally seen yet there

+Firefights are tricky in a good way since you cannot shoot through your own teammates and friendly grenades can kill you

+The look and feel of the game is pleasant and easy on the eyes. Yes people complain about the engine its on but its really quite decent. 

+There is a market where you can spend in game currency (not NXcoins) to buy attachments, guns and other things. But so far, the things I can unlock through play are equal if not better than the things I can buy. Not to mention a laser accessory that I could unlock is 9900 GP to buy compared to a 44000 market one.

+As for weapons, each one has its prime situation. Yes the sniper is OP in damage. Yes the AR is better at medium range. Yes the SMG is lighter and allows you to be more agile. Every weapon has a field it excels in and overall its balanced decently well. "Oh man this is so stupid. To get a better weapon I need to spend 200k GP. What a piece of BS". Again, no you dont. You -can- buy it if you want to but the first weapon you unlock is a MP5 or whatever and its pretty decent boosting pretty much all stats less some damage(barely) and effective range from the starter. Pfff, who needs range on a high ROF close range SMG.

+Community. So far every room I have had the pleasure of joining has been nice, friendly and all around enjoyable. Well except for the one guy who apparently was getting away with his bad internet and one guy always seemed to be on the receiving end aha. 

+Leveling and Currency. Now I'm not sure if it will stay like this but currently, as you level you get 50k GP to spend on things. "Wow! Thats a lot!â€ Why yes little Timmy it is. Seeing as you can get 500GP per loss up to 1000 on a win. Not that slow I'll say that much. You can level pretty fast as well. Of course getting more wins than losses speeds it up but I like to think with my current play time and level, I managed to average a little over a level in about an hour

 PRO/CON
 
+-I personally like the skill system. But Iâ€™ll put this as a PRO/CON since it comes up a lot in other discussions. At the beginning of a match you automatically start with your tier 1 skill (200points). As you get kills/assists/do game mode objectives, you get points that refill that gauge to a max of 400 points for the tier 2 level of the skill 

There are added benefits to saving up to tier 2 and not using your skill every time you can. FYI your skill has a cooldown meter to limit fast consecutive uses if you are on a bloody, messy, mass murdering killing spree. But during that time you may obtain points towards your next skill use. So its not all that bad. Even more reason to save up those precious points

I can see how people dislike it if your team is getting completely steam rolled and its hard to fill. But you automatically regen skill points until your skill bar reaches tier 1. Albeit slow, but its something. 

+-Hitboxes. Ah yes, the double edged sword. I like to think that its both, in its current state, helpful and frustrating. I also believe its not just the hitbox but the weapon firing as well that is also a contributing factor. More so the former though. Many times have I tried to gun down someone running up some stairs at me to have him take 25%-50% damage to only knife me in the animated melee kill. But also to run down a hallway away from 3 enemies firing auto weapons at me to get away and lead them unsuspectingly into a pod of my own team for the assists. As I said, it works both ways. Hoping it will get tweaked soon

+-Mobile Agility AKA "Parkour". A little rough around the edges. You cant jump very high so you cant climb on top to many things to either get a vantage spot or cut corners. Granted at this stage its both good and bad. It currently in a way levels the field so everyone is even. There are prompts to press W+Space to "vault" over/up small ledges but some things I hoped were climbable were unfortunately not  

+- Healing. Now some people are unhappy that you can't regenerate or heal completely. Cough Cough CoD Players Cough Cough. Well they are right up to a certain point. Now this game is listed as a Tactical Shooter if im not mistaken. So if you were able to just wait for your wounds to heal (looks at certain types of players) then get right back at it, where's the tactics? The stress of not taking damage? The thrill when you kill 3 people alone and survive with 3 hp left to only to feel useless afterwards because you will die to a flesh wound or graze of a bullet. Well fear not. 

Remember how earlier above I mentioned Tier 2 abilities? Well some of those are shareable. "Shareable? How does that work?' Play the game yourself and figure it out. KIDDING. Some abilities once you reach tier 2 are able to be "Downloaded" by up to 3 other operatives. But how does this relate to healing you ask? Well one operatives has Nano Armor I believe its called or whatever. In short, it allows the user and 3 other operatives to gain increased armor and health regen during its duration at tier 2 or just the user at tier 1. I like to think of these operative as either support or tactical roles. Look, there's that word again, tactical. Tactics. Strategy.

Now for the more unhappy part

CONS

- Matchmaking Balancing. I have gone into a match or two where it started as 5v2 and was really one sided. Granted players were matched onto the other team to balance it out, but not until the game was half over with a 20 kill lead. Thats something else I would hope gets fixed pretty soon.

- Glitches(not in game). Some people, myself including, who got one of the early access packs with a character unlock have not/ did not get our free character unlocks at lvl 3 and lvl 5. Currently I have a ticket with this problem sent and am waiting for a response, but will update this if possible with an answer to it. (Edit - Recieved)

-Only a few map types. In Team Deathmatch at least, there are only 3 maps. With the right strategy and team cooperation, either side of a maps starting point can be a winner. Some are less advantaged as others but can be sorted out if you push far enough to rotate the respawn points of the enemy team around. Which also brings me to another CON

-Spawning. I wont lie, I have taken advantage of this. Every once and a while ill go off out of a firefight to flank in from behind the enemy to only end up at their current respawn spot to get a few easy respawn kills before they realize it. Im not proud of it, just extorting this unfortunate algorithm of respawning in an area with enemies around. As I mentioned above the respawn point will move once too many get too close. But one, maybe even two people get there, then they get a few free kills before it realizes and moves. 

Honestly, I really do enjoy playing this game and I really like the concept, structure and form this game has. Sure its still a bit bare bones and what not. Its early access, give it a bit of a break. Things will be worked on, added, fixed, adjusted and tinkered with as it grows. 

But if you read all of this or even just took the time to skim it and pick out the certain things you wanted to know, thank you for your time. 

Overall Score - 8/10 | After over 1 year of playing the CBT of this game, and being a part of the community, and doing my best offering suggestions to make the game better, instead... nothing changes or is made worse:

-Weapons Are still Not balanced properly, no damage drop off (pistols are the only exception)
-Utility Grenades are STILL almost completely useless
-Stats are inconsistent and almost meaningless, the netcode that has gone from good to bad to TERRIBAD does not help this (Latest patch seems to have addressed the hitreg issue, not sure for how long though...)
-SMGs are still the best overall weapon in the game thanks to high RoF, low Recoil and being able to oneshot Headshot from 50 FUCKING meters, just like assault rifles :/ 
-Wonky desynced hitboxes and misaligned scopes and sights 
-Not having a Public Test Server SEPERATED from the main game for Random Dive matches where it can properly be tested...
-Removing Dedicated Playlists and treating ALL players like Guinea Pigs
-Treating us players NOT just like guinea pigs, but Piggy Banks as well with this nonsensical new F2P model~!!!
-More grind than ever, low XP gains and cutting rewards earned overall (you now get 20k GP instead of 50k per level, the grind starts to get awful by the time you get to level 20 too, and there are supposed to be 80 Levels TOTAL?!!), making market weapons more expensive (practically tripled in GP costs in the latest update), all so they can sell Boosters, Starter packs and FREAKING OPERATIVE LICENSES WITH NX?!! WHAT THE FUUUUUUUUU~!!!!

Pros:
-Ability System - I like the character abilities and the focus on team-play that results from having a good spread of abilities on the team.
-Original English VAs - Might seem like something minor in most games, but it shows dedication to be true to the source material to get the voice actors from the series to work on lines for the game.
-Teamplay Oriented - Not much to say here. If you pick your characters to have a balanced spread of abilities and play to their advantage, then you'll be much more successful.
-Interesting Approach to Advancement - Unlocking more mod slots as you play and having post-game drops that degrade over time but allow you to enhance your characters.

Cons:
-Therm-optic stealth isn't a blanket ability that everyone can use. - It would be much more interesting if the Major could hack -and- control enemy Think Tanks instead of being the only character able to cloak. 
- Can't Cook Grenades - You can pull the pin and hold it forever, it still won't effect how long it takes to explode after tossing it.
-Character Stacking - Anyone who has ever played TF2 can attest, having a team full of snipers is never a good sign. Having a team of eight people all playing the same character with the same ability isn't any better.
-Map Size - Not all of the maps suffer from this, but TDM levels are especially cramped.
-Useable Space - Some of the maps are of a decent size, however the usable area is very -very- flat. Sure there are sniper rifles in the game but good luck finding a decent vantage point to make good use of them.
-Spawn Protection - TDM is the main culplrit here, if you have enough people with cybersentries on your team you can lockdown a spawnroom and turn it into free kills until the game is over. 
-Freedom of Movement - The contextual movement system is alright, but when you can't go up a ladder because you were jumping and have to land then look up before climbing the ladder it just slows everything down.
-Togusa doesn't have a Mateba. | A huge update is rolling out soon, meaning this review is subject to change. Keep a look out. 

Every time this game updates I expect something to improve and really, that's not the case. My main issues with GitS: SAC - First Assault Online (apart from the ridiculous name) are as follows:

-Hit registration and lag compensation are horrible and it's been that way for a long time. This game has some very large issues with players being hit behind walls or before they can see enemies. Their most recent solution was to make this even worse with the upside of stopping laggers from rubber-banding- making the big issue worse to solve a smaller one. The hitreg is so bad that people are constantly accusing others of wallhacking and/or whining about hitreg ingame. 

-The large and growing weapon selection is pointless because the game has had the f2p policy of making everything require ingame credits, so you must either grind like crazy to get anything or buy everything with real-world cash. Attachments are costly and can only be used for the single weapon you purchase them for. The level-up rewards used to give 50k credit vouchers every level, but now they give 20k. Operatives (characters you play as who only differ in their special abilities) are expensive and you only receive a few vouchers at the start and from your first few levels. Unless you feel like dishing out a few hundred USD, you will never experience the full roster of characters and weapons this game has to offer- which brings me to my next complaint. 

-The weapons all have random spread and most OHKO on headshot. This makes high ROF (rate of fire) weapons extremely likely to headshot you (but if they don't it's fine, kills take 3-4 shots. 3 if you're using an AR w/ a damage barrel and hit center mass, 2 if  you're using an MG with damage barrel. Most snipers one-hit anywhere when within range and shotguns use this funky mechanic where their spread reduces while ADS (aiming down sights) as if they magically get a barrel choke, meaning every shot is essentially a prayer to RNGesus). Certain weapons are extremely easy to use and get adopted very quickly- it happened with the C30 and later the f2020 (both ARs with high damage and rates of fire). People have been complaining for an f2020 nerf ever since it was released and it still has not happened. TTK (time to kill) has been too high since release and nothing has been done to change that. 

-Missions with player rewards tend to be extremely time-intensive/grindy and offer meager rewards. Examples include getting grenade triple kills, getting a very high number of kills with grenades and 2 specific pistols, planting an insanely high number of bombs (and defusing) in demolition mode (where you might be lucky to plant 1-3 times and defuse once or twice unless you try to do nothing but plant and defuse). Weapon rewards from these missions that are already owned by the player means the player gets essentially nothing from the mission- no refunds on bought weapons/attachments. When an expensive weapon skin was a mission reward, people argued that since it cost 10 USD on the market, it was justified. I argue that there's no reason for a simple weapon reskin to cost that much besides greed. Even if 10 USD was fair, think of it as less than 2 hours of minimum wage pay. How long will the mission take? 4-5 hours? Maybe more- and if your game time counted as work, you'd be getting paid a fraction of minimum wage for your time. That's insulting. That's not all, either. 

-The new ingame gambling system is disgusting. About a day after it dropped, I'd already heard of multiple experiences where people had funneled a lot of money into it and gotten nothing. There's now a third kind of ingame currency meant to be generated from the meager refunds you get off items you didn't want. It's like they took the pointless gambling aspect of CS:GO and then removed all other methods of item aquisition like trading and the market. Skins (reskins for guns) and outfits (reskins/outfit changes to operatives) are presented as being extremely valuable but are really clearly just a cash grab. 

-The game is horribly optimized, takes ages to load, suffers from stutters, and looks 6 years old to boot. 

-There are only 2 server joining options. The big one is dive, which means that the game selects whatever server and mode for you. You will be sent back to servers you wanted to leave.The other is private match, where you can play on servers with next to no one besides 1v1s that are full. No community server or server browser option has been implemented. 

-Maps are small and suffer from annoying chokepoints as hard as any tactical shooter- except this game is trying to be paced more run-and-gun. The result is an odd mix of campers and people hopping around firing automatics from the hip. It's frustrating and makes modes like Terminal Conquest impossible to carry because of the inevitable wall of enemies suppressing you from halfway across the map at all times. There are moments where you can get away with satisfying multikills, utilizing your secondary and such, but die from it because some scrub respawned behind you and killed you with a random headshot. This might not reflect everyone's experience but I know I'm guilty of taking advantage of bad respawns and stupidly long lines of sight to get kills far too easily and still I hate when it happens to me. 

-No matter how many times we complain about something and recommend good features like server browser, the devs fail to respond. On the discussion boards, the community manager Lumos is happy to respond to a good number of posts but I haven't seen this game take any steps towards being noteworthy. 

I'd like to like this game but I can't. I'll still check it out after major updates to see if it's improved, but my hopes are not high. It's another Asian FPS cashgrab. 

There's much more that could go into this review but I've used enough space as is. If you'd like to know more, add me and I'll answer any questions.

edit: will be doing ingame testing to confirm map problems etc. nothing has improved yet but I've stirred up some interest with this review. | Comment dire...

I HATED every second of this game. 
There is no love in this game, only lust, and it's just because the female lead is the only female on their team. The only man who seems to genuinely love and care for the female lead doesn't even have his own route and is a measly side character. I've seen a lot of reviews from other women complaining about the sexual harassment in this game, and they're right to do so. I wish I had seen their reviews before I spent any money buying this awful game. 

If you're wondering what it may contain, miscommunication trope is a common theme in this game. The female lead doesn't actually fight back, she just weakly says "no" and the men do not respect her enough to stop hurting her. The female lead is CONSTANTLY insulted about her looks, how she dresses, and seen as incompetent compared to her male coworkers. 

One man in particular left me feeling particularly annoyed, and he was Ryo Kaido. He had a few nasty quotes, including "You were such an amateur. And I got to mold you and change you... And you changed beyond anything I could have hoped for." Where is this romance in this stuff? There's no love in this, he just bullied her into being submissive and then bragged about ruining her personality (which was already plain enough).

Cute game with a simple concept, though it could use a few optimizations. Of course clickers require clicking, but the upgrades fully maxed don't bring the ease one would expect for collecting things compared to others in the genre. You don't just need to click, but you need to do it rather quickly. Something that would help would be traps for the dragonflies, snails, frogs, lizards, and snakes. Some sort of stats page would also be nice considering the achievements require specific numbers and it can be easy to feel overwhelmed without having a point of reference so one can know where to focus. A second screen location featuring a shop front or way to deliver the items made would also be an improvement, the art is VERY good looking but only hanging out on the outside of the hut gets really dull over time. It feels like it should be more of an idler with the lack of usual clicker upgrades but it also feels like it was made with care. | A fine clicker game. Only big complaint is that the game seems to slow down quite a bit as I was unlocking the last achievements due to how much was on screen. | This game is nice for when you want to play something without thinking and paying attention. Also good to play while listening to a podcast. 
Easy to 100% the achievments.

Like the previous reviewer, I was initially turned off by the weird game description. But I wasn't going to kick it until I tried it. 

Pros
Character design
Reminiscent of a Korean romantic comedy

Cons
Inconsistent music loop 
Blurry backgrounds
Lack of depth
Cliche plot elements

Some of the pros and cons I listed could be taken either way. But here, I'll discuss my personal opinion of the game. (I know it says I've only docked about 11 hours, but I really did get all the acheivements already.)

The story starts out with you, the protagonist, newly transformed after undergoing plastic surgery to impress your fiance (slightly weird thing to do, considering he's already agreed to marry you, but it's good. lol). Later on, using your stalking skills and the help of a handsome stranger, you find out that he's actually a con man who tricks women into marriage. After returning home, you get a call from your fiance asking to borrow money, but you had spent it all on the surgery, so he breaks up with you. And thus, your otome dating sim begins.

Right off the bat, I assumed this game would be your typical, cringy, dating sim. And I'm actually really into that (I've played so many Dogenzaka lab games lol), so I went into it with a very open mind. 

I really liked the art style in this game, specifically the CGs and character sprites. One thing that bothered me a bit was the way the protagonist was drawn (no eyes), but that is a minor detail. The backgrounds were disappointing and looked like blurry pictures, which has worked for other games, but these specific photos looked bad (maybe I'm just being picky?). The music also seemed familiar, maybe recycled from another game, though it was pleasant enough. I got the impression that the creators didn't invest as much time into this game compared to some of their other titles.

Above, I mentioned that the story reminded me of a Korean romantic comedy (which I'm not that into, so I listed it as a pro for others rather than myself). I found the protagonist a bit silly, with her clumsiness and stalkish behavior, made me chuckle a few times. She wasn't too passive overall, so the choices weren't ridiculously frustrating, which was a plus. A surprisingly common element in this game was that the characters were engaged to someone else from the beginning. Personally, I'm not interested in pursuing this type of character, so I didn't like that aspect either. And though the characters had great designs and personalities, I didn't feel an emotional attachment to any them or their stories. The suitors seemed cliche (e.g. rich doctor, model, CEO who sweeps you off your feet). Halfway into most of the routes, I lost interest. I can honestly say the story got pretty freakin' weird at times, but it still wasn't enough to keep me captivated. 

What I liked the most about this game was the obvious message and overall theme that beauty isn't only skin deep. Sadly, the protagonist had already gone under the knife before realizing any of that. And in a way, her beauty makes me question the integrity of some of these characters. It's likely that most of them wouldn't have even interacted with her, had she not undergone plastic surgery to be such a stand out beauty. 

Even though I liked it, this has been my least favorite of the Dogenzaka lab games I've played. Now, if you are a fan of kdramas, romantic comedies, strange storylines, or you just need something to pass the time, then you might enjoy this more than I did. Overall, I give it a 5/10. Not that great of a game, but I've certainly played worse. I'm not really recommending it, but I'm not saying you shouldn't give it a chance. | I really wanted to like this game. The prologue was funny and zany, but after that? It went downhill fast. The character I chose to romance, Akira, was pushy, cruel, and cheating on his ACTUAL GIRLFRIEND. 

From what I understand, all of the options are currently dating someone else while the MC tries to seduce them away. 

[spoiler]Akira's girlfriend, Yuka, is a cute plus-size girl in lolita fashion. In her case, she is extremely selfish, and when Akira has to go to the hospital because of a 102 degree fever, Yuka bursts in and yells at him for missing their date the night before. So the only chubby girl we see in-game is a screechy shrew who Akira only likes because he's a chubby chaser. Akira is trying to date MC at the same time as a "beard", or cover, so no one finds out his actual girlfriend is fat. 

Akira is also very aggressive and repeatedly ignores MC's attempts to say no to him, and at one point I was actually concerned he was going to [i]rape[/i] MC in an elevator. He had his hand up her skirt and was continually ignoring her refusal. [/spoiler]

After [i]six chapters[/i] of this, I was done. Despite my best attempts, I could not like Akira at all. 

The goofiness of the concept was quickly overshadowed by the complete lack of consideration for MC from all of the potential romance options. I couldn't finish even my first playthrough. | å¿«è¿›å®ŒçœŸæ˜¯é•¿å‡ºä¸€å£æ°”

Si alguien lo disfruta, me alegrarÃ© mucho por ella/Ã©l. Hay gustos para todos los tipos y siempre es mejor pasÃ¡rselo bien. | This is one of the better VNs by Dogenzaka. After running through 2 terrible ones, this one was a breath of fresh air.

Basic plot: The player character is self conscious and decides to get plastic surgery after her boyfriend proposes to her. [spoiler]Soon after, the player learns that her boyfriend was actually a con artist trying to launder money from her. He breaks up with her once he finds out that she spent all of the money he was going to launder on plastic surgery. The player then gets involved with one of the five romanceable guys, who all turn out to have a fiancee/girlfriend. The player starts to stalk them out of interest. The relationships are either one sided or had a fatal flaw within them. Eventually, the guy breaks off the relationship/engagement because he fell in love with the player[/spoiler].

The VN still has the problems that all other Dogenzaka VNs have. The 5 storylines are much better written than some of their other VNs published by Dogenzaka. They're 13 chapters + 2 endings rather than 8 chapters + 2 endings. There was actually character development compared to some of the other ones. I would actually recommend this one, even though there are some obvious flaws in it. The awkward translations are less noticeable in this one. The premise is weird, but it wasn't weird to the point where it's cringey.

If you plan on buying this game, get it in the bundle or wait until a sale.

I used to love this game when it first came out, as it reminded me of Swords and Potions 2, a game I played for many many years. Cloudcade was scheduled to take over S&P2, but in the end it didn't go through.

They made this game however, and back then it was a great game. They communicated nicely with their player base and I have even given them many ideas to make gameplay better, including ideas that are implemented in game. I felt appreciated and thus I loved supporting them.

I recently returned to play again, and enjoyed it a lot, until I ran into trouble that wasn't there before. They made changes in game to punish new players and to reward their old. As new player, you get many restrictions that make you even more behind on the older players than you already were.

They want you to pay for everything, and their ingame packages are extremely expensive. 

When you start to talk to cloudcade themselves, they are extremely rude and disregard you in every possible way. Sadly, it has begun to feel like an unfair game to new players, and I suggest not getting started on this one. It's a nice game, but extremely unfair and it's only there to fill their pockets with your hardearned cash. 

They even make fun of you if you have more accounts (different platforms) and let you know it is not allowed, even though you just started the game on different places and you can't help you can't link them to the other places. So it's your fault that they don't give you the option to log in from one place on different places. They are funny sometimes. Blame the players and not the company!

Not even worth 1 star. It's hard to believe that in 2025 we are still witnessing pro-Russian narratives in the gaming industry. In the latest version of the game, the developers once again ignored Ukrainian localization and completely erased the Ukrainian nation, which is heroically fighting for its survival and independence.  

The announcement of a new character, a tsarina-murderer being portrayed as a "symbol of culture and enlightenment," is a slap in the face to millions of Ukrainians. Glorifying an imperialist figure is not only outrageous but also immoral in the context of the war and occupation Ukraine is enduring today.  

Ukrainians deserve respect in the gaming industry, not an attempt to promote imperial narratives disguised as "cultural values." Enough with the propaganda! We demand full Ukrainian localization, Ukrainian heroes, and characters that truly reflect our history, culture, and struggle.

The game really don't have any difficulty to speak of, and is far longer than expected, so it may have some trouble holding your attention, but overall it's an adorable time with the world's most optimistic bard. | A very fun platformer style game, with tons of puzzles and (you guessed it) music shenanigans. Gameplay is fairly intuitive and easy to pick up, and I will say that the game has its moments with some of the puzzles being more complex as the story progresses. The story itself is a very fun spin on the Chosen One trope too, with plenty of character growth happening for both the Main cast and some of the side characters (especially if you are someone like me, as I spoke with the NPCs quite frequently).

In my giant Steam library, I've never had a game crash more than this one. It's fun, but be prepared for a lot of angry fist pumps when the game crashes on your sweet build. |

1 it's digimon

cons

Number 6 happened to me twice before i knew the game machanics and how to move from the town to the main area and back again, so I restarted (losing all of my good progress having to restart the extremely long tutoriel again) and started playing again and kept playing and it happened again and it kept on appearing breaking battles causing my digimon to keep losing health all because of stupid pop-ups. Yeah it's fun, but would you really want to play a game that is hard to even play through? Just think about that.

 | PAY TO PLAY!
Ho provato questo gioco perchÃ¨, come molti di voi, sono un fan del franchise Digimon. Ho sempre desiderato poter avere un gioco dove io sono un digimontamer che con il suo digimon vaga per il Mondo digitale costruendo la sua avventura quest dopo quest. Capirete la mia delusione quando ho capito dopo varie ore passate a giocarci che non esiste una "storia principale".. ovviamente le quest si dividono in "main" e "sub" che erÃ² sono sempre, e dico SEMPRE, identiche! Esempio: parlo con un NPC in un punto A della mappa che mi dice di uccidere un numero tot di digimon (dei Leomon, per esempio) che si trovano nel punto B, quindi tu vai nel punto B, uccidi la quantitÃ  di digimon richiesta e ritorni al punto A. Una volta tornato lÃ  l'NPC ti dirÃ  ritorna nel punto B e uccidi altri Leomon finchÃ¨ non ti droppano un numero tot di Denti di Leomon (ancora per esempio). Quindi tu torni nel punto B e cominci ad uccidere uno dietro l'altro tutti i Leomon che ti capitano a tiro fichÃ¨ non hai raccolto tutti gli strumenti richiesti (tra l'altro con un sistema di drop veramente basso, soprattutto nelle missioni piÃ¹ avanzate). Dopo di chÃ¨, una volta ritornati al punto A lo stesso NPC ti dirÃ  di fare ancora le stesse cose, magari combiando il digimon bersaglio o mappa ma questo Ã¨ quanto.. e stiamo parlando del 99% delle quest e stiamo parlando di quelle piÃ¹ "divertenti". Le altre si limiteranno a chiederti di andare da un punto A ad un punto B, parlare con un NPC e tornare indietro; o ad analizzare dei digimon nella mappa.
Un'altra cosa che non mi Ã¨ piaciuta assolutamente, e che Ã¨ in sostanza quella per cui non mi piace veramente questo gioco, Ã¨ il sistema di farming e di hatching dei digiuovi.. mi spiego. Ogni volta che uccidi un digimon si ha una percentuale di probabilitÃ  in cui tu puoi ottere il suo digiuovo che tramite l'utilizzo di dei "chip dati" del tipo di digimon e di una macchina incubatrice puoi schiudere per ottere, appunto, quel particolare digimon. Dove sta il problema? Il problema Ã¨ che non solo droppare un digiuomo e decisamente lungo e noioso ma la maggior parte delle volte il digiuovo che si cerca di far schiudere nell'incubatrice si rompe e quindi lo perdi irrimediabilmente, sprecando non solo i "chip dati" raccolti precedentemente ma anche molto e molto tempo!
In conclusione, si Ã¨ carina l'idea ma nient'altro. Se vi volete bene statene alla larga.
Ps: ancora due righe sulla community.. che Ã¨ veramente pessima. Ah, e avete presente l'inglese? Dimenticatevelo, qui si parla solo spagnolo.

I "Kombined" stuff. and used my brain to get through these challenges. 
Joke aside, it's a fun little game.

would be better as a screensaver or moving wallpaper. it's just a simple environment that you fly around, no goals or story and not a lot you can actually 'do'. it calls itself 'immersive' but you can't even land (correction, you can land on some very specific perches but nothing else, and i only found this out by checking discussions) and when you hit things you just get pushed back in time so you can avoid the collision, rather than it having consequences or any kind of physics. there seem to be a few things you can interact with (like fruit and pinwheels) but no reason to do so, except some structures you can fly through change your appearance or the bg music. i would rather have gotten to choose my bird at the start, and for music to simply change naturally like a radio.

keyboard controls were also jank, but even after switching to controller, i did not feel like a bird and i didn't see any reason to keep playing instead of just putting on a video of someone else doing it. only positives are the free achievement just for launching the game and a brief few minutes where my cat saw the bird on the screen and got interested, but even she soon grew bored.

i think i was expecting something like 'AER; Memories of Old', which i didn't know of when i bought this game. this seems to just be a very watered down version of that game. if feather at least had achievements for collecting the different birds or interacting with different things, and let you land anywhere, i could maybe get behind it. the total lack of direction and forced constant flight were big negatives in a game where the only real positive is 'it's pretty'.

I play this game for the feeling of nostalgia it gives. Like I am some how teleported back to my parents bedroom playing Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis. Cosas positivas: 
+ La idea estÃ¡ muy bien.

+ Tienes que pensar bien que cartas usar para mejorar a tus soldaditos. (Aunque la estrategia no va mucho mÃ¡s allÃ¡)

Cosas negativas: 
- Una vez llegas a la quinta isla empieza a ser aburrido 
- Los balances del dinero estÃ¡n mal equilibrados

- No estÃ¡ en mÃ¡s idiomas sino en inglÃ©s (Aunque tampoco hay que saber demasiado para entender el juego)

Me dejo muchas cosas, como que tal es la mÃºsica y demÃ¡s. TambiÃ©n hay que tener en cuenta que el juego no ha sido terminado y que es gratuito. | Beginner Tips
1. Rush gold farm, better to build adventure quest at early. map 3 and 4 is good place
2. Rush bosses = start farming as many chest as early, the 4,8 and 12 hr wait time is killing
3. Rush new map = more Guildian / farm
4. Level the quest which you have bonus is better if you have x10 or more
5. I reset the monster,xp quest at map 6, 7 to lv1 after unlocking the boss, other quest all adventure, easy farm and guildian die less
6. Map 5 quest 16 - 24 for xp quest farm
Spoiler http://steamcommunity.com/id/imfearless/screenshot/156899501290589681
7. Sometime it is better to have lower lv quest or cut half the road 
Spoiler http://steamcommunity.com/id/imfearless/screenshot/156899501290545579
8. The debate of leaving the game on and afk for boss chest or go offline for more gold / xp
9. If you like this game, then its good to get the beginner bundle and unlock thief class, you have  time till map 3,4 to test if you like the game ( also where it become more difficult)
10. Boss chest give xp, gold, card, guildian and GEMS! (Cash shop currency at a low rate but the most important !)

Overall a fruitfull, relaxing and uplifting expierence. I had great fun and joy. | Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War is a turn based rpg educational game that uses katakana characters as the monsters with the player 'attacking' with the romaji or English sound of said katakana character. This game features a number of refinements over the Hiragana version.

One of the refinements in the katakana game over the hiragana game is menu layout is much better and easier to locate the command the player wishes to use laid out in a, i, u, e, o. Which greatly speeds up the player's ability to locate what they are looking for. Although at the time of this review (I'm at na, ni, nu, ne, no), I have not reached ya, yu, yo or wa, wo to figure out how the game handles them. I'd still prefer keyboard entries over the menu, but this game is not nearly as frustrating in menu navigation. 

Additionally, this game has the party members execute their 'attack' individually instead of the player forced to select all party member's actions before starting 'combat'. This change made the game quite fun for me. Even if I haven't reached any katakana characters i didn't already have memorized before playing. This alone is a huge improvement over the hiragana survive game.

The game also features swappable party members. Which actually had me wanting to grind/practice areas I've cleared. Not a bad thing in an educational game. The 'monster' encounters are done more like Zelda II instead of like Final Fantasy/Dragon Warrior if you know those NES games. And I found that to also be an excellent quality of life improvement. I could seek out harder or easier groups of katakana character monsters for more or less practice. Rather than them just sprung on me.

As mentioned, I've already familiarized myself with most katagana before starting to play this game. I would recommend prospective players to do the same. At the time of this review, I have hiragana memorized and about 75% of katakana. The game is more about reinforcing and finishing memorizing last little bit. I think using flashcard and spending time writing each character daily is still fundamental with the game as support in learning.

I actually couldn't recommend the hiragana game in this series. I found it a little too frustrating with too much time spent navigating menus to be effective even for support learning. However, this katakana game fixes enough of those issues as well as some things I didn't know I had an issue with for an enjoyable game. And in fact, there is a bit of traditional turn-based rpg here as well. The player needs to use party/monster turn order, character damage and monster hit points (katakana monsters  become more powerful further into the 'alphabet' you get) to dispatch them with minimal harm to your party.

I do recommend Learn Japanese To Survive! Katakana War. With the understanding the game is much more enjoyable if you study away from it. | Like Hiragana, this is definitely a decent tool to help you learn, while you practice at the beginning. It does fade off fast though and you will likely out pace the game. | Great tools to learn katakana just like the previous game but it got some improvment here and there
thank you for creating this game, make it easier for someone like me to learn japanese

So much content and progression done the right way without everwhelming you. Plus the devs are constant updating some little things to improve the game that I can call the most strategical game of all clickers/idles haha.. love it. | [h1]A Fantastic Clicker Game For Clicker Fans[/h1]

[bFinally a Clicker Heroes competitor that shows promise[/b]

Having played Clicker Heroes for ages and ages, and sadly not being able to find anything to compare, I'm blown away by this game. 

I've yet to see if it holds up the the thousands of hours I've put into Clicker Heroes, but I can certainly say that it has kept my attention for the hours I've already played it. 

[b]Intricate systems with layer after layer of depth[/b]

One of the biggest problems with clicker games is that, unless the dev really understands the need for multiple upgrade systems, these games often fail to last more than a few thousand clicks. Midas Gold Plus is so deep with restart systems, leveling up of skills and characters, raids, bonuses, boosts, etc, that it just pleases the player, left right and center. 

[b]A new reason to sit at the computer and lose yourself in a game[/b]

I've been at the computer for a pretty lengthy time, already today, just leveling up stats, buying upgrades, and watching the gold come flying in. Even better, when I'm out and about, I am actually excited to come back and see what my idle time has unlocked and opened in the game. The fact is, the feedback loop of this game is extremely intelligent in that it rewards the player in very positive ways. 

[b]Rewarding experiences for different play styles[/b]

As you play the game, you begin to unlock advisors which have bonuses that you can use during your play. In the beginning, there are two, one rewards you with bonuses for clicking, one rewards you with idle bonuses. Later in the game (I've yet to unlock more) there are advisors with even stranger skill sets. You can change your advisor on the fly, so if you're at the computer, select the guy with skills that reqard clicking, if you go out, select the one who rewards idle time. 

It's painless and easy to switch advisors, and each time you switch, you have a bunch of new bonuses and boosts to use your money on to upgrade. 

[b]A must download for clicker fans[/b]

This game is free. Simply put, even without paying a single penny, you'll enjoy this game if you enjoy clicker games. It's simply just perfectly thought out, very rewarding, and progresses at a wonderful pace, whether you pay real money or not.

Additionally, if you DO decide to pay real money, the packages are very fairly priced, and the "Hot Deals" packages are fantastic bonuses that supercharge the gameplay from the get-go. 

If you are a fan of clicker games, and you are on the fence about this game, take it from me. It's well designed, rewarding, deep as the sea, and fantastic fun. 

Quit reading this review and download the damn game, for goodness sakes. Geesh, some people take so much convincing...

Bugs still preset.
Got to a higher level zone than normal, quit for the night, log back in to have 0.0 Gold and to have gotten "0.0 Gold while away"  to make matters worse - no gold pick up would work, having to forcefully use the rebirth system to get any gold at all.

No fixes in nearly a yaer?  Unprofessional.  Would be a fun, hard, clicker game if not for all the bugs that literally break the game progress and force restarting before ready, and reward so little your power never feels like it's going up.

Still do not reccomend the game, still has original problems and more. Doesn't look like the company knows what it is doing. Avoiding "Fox Dawn" now, another junk Dev/Publisher that is trying to make a quick buck without finishing the games they start.



// Original Post//
Too many problems to enjoy.
Balance issue is terrible.
Away bug not giving/displaying proper gold (forcing to keep playing if you want to advance at all)
Giant Brick wall that can only be avoided if you go to zone 3, ascend, repeatedly and use the "free stars" to boost your world STR/Crit so you can do more DPS. (very boring process too)  By repeatedly I mean over 100x as each time only seems to give 5 stars.

DPS doesn't increase past level 150.  Known bug- no fix.
Skills not working at all - or shutting off early - or not working properly in general.  Skill use is also extremely clunky - as you go to another tab/menu, scroll down to use it, and if you return to the buy heroes it's at the top again too - very cumbersome to always start at top of scroll lists instead of "where you left off"

This game should NOT have been released as/is - it is a ALPHA game as it is, and should be addressed properly. (Alpha means there are core problems being worked out or added to it that will shape the entire game, like adding Jumping to a platform game)

Fox Dawn needs to re-think how to balance things for the Gold required to level up the heroes VS the damage they dish out - relying too heavily on RNG Equipment drops is poor game mechanics.

Game breaking bugs and ignoring the community for, as of this review, two months after release.

Absolutely awesome game with great features (loot drop) that I really like for a clicker/idle, but due to the nasty issues with gold, skill calculation and useless leveling up heroes past level 150, please just pass.

Feel free to fire it up due to it being "free" and check out how much this game CAN be great, but do as I did and spend zero real money as you will rapidly realize your cash was wasted by sending to a development team that vanished after Steam release.

Edit: March 28, 2017
1.5 months AFTER posting the above review, the top unpinned discussion is still asking if the devs are ignoring the game...

"A very fun game with friends, I was hoping for a new installment with more competitive ideas. I recommend purchasing the game, but youâ€™ll need friends to fully enjoy it."

Je n'ai pas trouvÃ© le jeu difficile, cependant il m'a fallut 69 heures pour dÃ©bloquer la totalitÃ© des succÃ¨s.

Only played for a little bit on PC.
It is the same, without ads, and of course, on a bigger screen.
Pretty addictive, simple, yet fascinating.

You *can* play it like a traditional, turn based RPG game,
Or as a simple management game.

You can attack manually, or let your party attack by themselves.
Choose the gear you FIND in dungeons (or buy in the shop for dirt cheap) 
or let them be equipped automatically.

Manage different classes, items, boosts, powers, items, in a very simple yet effective way.

The best of all is you DON'T need to pay even a cent, EVERYTHING if unlockable with igc (in game currency) 
what you *HAVE* to do is recruit 5 adventurers, the rest is optional (and fun) | ....Why am I addicted to this game? I shouldn't be addicted to clicker games.... 8/10

Dropped about 75 hours into it years ago and completed all the puzzles in the base game. Just coming back to it now to play some of the community made puzzles as well and from the looks of it that may keep me busy for a bit. Good relaxing game to play when streaming TV or movies on the other monitor, | Really great picross/nonogram game! The puzzles are fun and unique, and what's pretty different about this one is that it has quite a few more difficult puzzles, whereas I feel like most picross games give you a flood of 5x5s and 10x10s and then only hand you a couple of 30x30s at the end. Pictopix gives you a good number of large puzzles that actually get harder as you progress. The last level was a real treat as well. Game Name: Weather Lord: Royal Holidays Collector's Edition
Reviews: Ğ½ĞµÑ‚

I believe Pikuniku stands out the most in terms of its gameplay style. It has a very unique and interesting style, as its graphics, dialogues, and even the way the in-game sport, baskick, is integrated into the main storyline make it special. What's particularly fun is that baskick can be played with a friend in offline multiplayer mode, making it a great party game as well.

The game's graphics fit perfectly with its style, though they are not the main focus, which means it can run smoothly even on a low-end "potato" PC. The dialogues are excellently written, and the characters are hilarious. One of the best things about the game, in my opinion, is the ability to play with a friend, whether it's the aforementioned baskick tournament or shorter levels designed for co-op gameplay.

Another impressive aspect of the game is the movement of NPCs. Their animations are so well done that they almost feel like real players. This is especially noticeable during the baskick tournament or when you start kicking an NPCâ€”after a while, they will even fight back!

Overall, I think Pikuniku is a fantastic and entertaining game that is definitely worth its price. | ---{ Ğ“Ñ€Ğ°Ñ„Ğ¸ĞºĞ° }-â€”

I'm on the fence with this one since it's a bit too easy and monotonous for adults, and might be too frustrating for kids. Maybe it's just not for me, but it's not a bad game overall. I've noticed some people recommending a guide - I would definitely advise against it unless you are twelve. 

The good:
- cat purring sounds
- lots of small beautifiers like tiny penguins spawning during winter
- lighting
- diverse biomes

The bad:
-  crafting, where you need to click 50 times to craft 50 items (and watch a small animation every time)
- animal pathfinding is the worst
- navigating the map  - it's challenging (and not in a good way) to find a way to a certain spot on a map
- dying in the water and casually appearing on the shore gives me an eery feeling
- characters feel lifeless and their stories are uninteresting
- lots of fetch quests, no real challenges
- Teagin Gabardine's beard and mullet combo | Â

10/10 Made some real masterpieces in this! | Das Spiel ist seltsam. 40 min gespielt und an sich ist nichts passiert. Da kann man die Zeit besser mit Krita verbringen und tatsÃ¤chlich was malen, also mit richtigen Pinseln, Werkzeugen, Ebenen, Farbmischungen usw. Das Spiel hier scheint lediglich darin zu bestehen, Bilder zu verkaufen - in der Hoffnung man trifft den Geschmack der Kunden. Und irgendwann - ja wann denn eigentlich endlich? - ein paar Werkzeuge dazu zu kaufen. Und dann damit weiter zu machen, wie zuvor. 

Ich bin gespannt, ob der zweite Teil etwas mehr Inhalt bietet. (den Rezensionen nach wohl leider auch nicht) | A relaxing experience

It was fun to paint and paint in the beginning, but got too repetitive later

Not worth the full price (if you don't have patience to paint and paint with no action like me), it's fun to return to the game once in a while and paint characters from new games you play, buy if it's on sale

pros
+solid plot
+Asian Culture(i mean the red string of fate)
+soothing soundtrack
+free game with achievements and 4 endings.
+have included choice for different ending
+7hours of gameplay for 4ending might be longer( if you plan to read the same thing 4 times at the start of the game)

cons

Overall:it is not much to complain about the game since this is free to play and i suggest people to try it out.you won't regret on playing this interesting story.although most of the time i kinda pity Valerie for her naive personality. | Cute and Compelling.
I play a LOT of visual novels, and I wasn't expecting much out of Red String of Fate, just another otome without much in the way of characters or story. Imagine my surprise when I found myself enjoying the game. Luke and Aaron are two very unique and interesting characters, I found myself actually entranced by the story and their personal character arcs. Luke is my favored of the two, but Aaron is not without charm. The premise is also interesting, and pretty unique, which is key to making a good visual novel. 
My biggest complaint is the length. I found the stories to be sadly short and too few to justify their length. The pacing was also strange at times, but not terrible. I also wish there was a "rewind" function so if I acciendentally skipped a piece of text, I could just go back and see what I had missed instead of losing track of the conversation.
Overall a good game, would definitely recomend, but has room for improvement and leaves little to no replay value. | As someone who played a lot of free visual novels on steam I can safely say Red String of Fate is one of the better ones (although that's not that hard to achieve (â”€â€¿â€¿â”€) ) .

Red String of Fate is a comedy otome. You play as Valerie a student that can see other peoples red strings of fate(red cord that's connects people that are destined to meet one another ). The story itself is great and well paced although some of the dialogue could be a little better. The characters are likable and interesting. There is four possible endings.

The art and music are well done. It fits well with a theme and tone of the game.
Interface is also good(something you can't say for a lot of free VNs on steam).

And at the end its free and small in download size. If I had to score it I would give it 7.5/10.

Ps. Choose Luke (^Ì®^)

Note: I've already played this game on itch.io while I was waiting for it to release on steam. | Red String of Fate, story wise its one of the more decent visual novels on Steam I would say.  I would recommend it to any visual novel fans. It is very short, so there is not a lot of investment required. This is a fun game that is super easy to learn.  It has it's difficult moments but overall quite a laid back experience.  Cat Quest reminds me of my old SNES days, kind of a Zelda type hack n slash.  Tons of cat related puns so it keeps  you smiling.  Basic equipment types, swords, battle axes, staves, but a number of each kind with their own buffs and debuffs.  Definitely worth buying especially on sale.  It took me about 7.5 hours to complete the main quest and about an extra hour to complete what was left of the 62 sidequests. Fun time waster, but I'm glad it's cheap. The gameplay is quite good but there's no real difficulty option or curve.

If you're going to play against the AI, it doesn't take advantage of fields very much. You can really cheese out some victories by dropping down some meeple to snatch up a good 30-50 additional points that way, which more often than not ends up being the deciding factor in the game. (Much like in the real life board game.)

That said, I own multiple versions of this game, to include the IRL version. One thing that kind of irks me that this game doesn't do is allow for multiple base sets to be played for a longer game. Laying down a colossal amount of tiles for a long-play has always felt part and parcel with Carcassonne (especially IRL), and that experience is missing from this one. | It's a good game, i play it a lot with my friend but CAN YOU PLEASE UPDATE IT, IT'S BUGGY AS HELL! | Great strategy game that is more complex than it first appears. The skill parts of the game involve thinking about how to use the puzzle pieces in ways that help you score points but also make your opponents castles difficult to finish. Playing against all humans in person is much more fun than a computer game cause when you pull that killer tile against your buddies and know exactly where to place it for full advantage...it is very satisfying when a good plan comes together!  If you like Catan but get 2D12 dice fatigue, this game is perfect. No Dice in Carcasonne means less luck and more skill. Also, i highly recommend the expansion packs. The basic game with the River is an ok starting point, but get the packs for variety | perfect adaptation. so much easier to keep track of scoring (especially fields) than playing the physical game | Hele leuke game, ook dat je niet alle kaarten meer op tafel hoeft te leggen en nadien weer te moeten sorteren en opbergen, bespaard veel tijd, alleen jammer dat niet alle uitbreidingen op DLC beschikbaar zijn. Zalige game voor uren, alle regels goed kennen is een vereiste.
