Game Name: Wild West Saga: Idle Tycoon Clicker
Genres: Casual, Free To Play, Indie, Simulation
Reviews: No Reviews

Too slow to be enjoyable for me.  

Decent ideas, but getting interrupted too often for the tutorial for a game this simple should not be a thing.  Slow mo for every single ability shouldn't be a thing.  Waiting several seconds to reset to fire again should not be a thing.  Just plodding and dull.

2/5 | It's a fun concept on paper, but it doesn't really work well. I really wanted to like this game, because it has some cool art and concepts and it looks well developed. But the chore mechanic is broken. You are supposed to hit the enemies, but then you get punished when you do that. Having a health bar for this type of games is just disastrous. It really takes the joy out of the game. | A skillful balance between relaxing and challenging-enough-to-stay-interesting. | It's good.... it's just not peggle.

Eh.  
It COULD be a fun game.  It doesn't really start you off well, during the tutorial phase.  The graphics are small, the controls kind of hard to find, and after I'd done a few tasks, I didn't really feel the need to do more.  I'll try reading through the documentation and see if I'm more invested at that point, but they can definitely do more to make the game a fun start. | A calming point & click simulator, with eye-catching visuals, and a relaxing soundtrack. The game play loop is calming, the customization diverse, with my only complaint being that I wish there were more things in the game (more animals, plants, and a bigger map.) I would highly recommend this game. | It is a very good game, good mechanics but a little tough to play on a laptop, would recommend it is very relaxing | At the start this game was fine but later is was really boring, nothing spreads or goes over set limits meaning nothing really happens at all. Also why do I need to do 500 tasks to get some random flower I want??? It takes forever and is just really boring | It's so much fun! Relaxing, cute, i love the chunky polygon graphics. It's almost sims city building like but with nature

A nice dice-rolling roguelike

+ Unique mechanics for each class
+ Fresh Final Stage
+ Although the theme is a bit light, at times the game dialogues were fun to watch

- A bit on the easy side
- AI not always finding the optimal move
- Not all enemies feel unique | I hate rouguelikes and rougelites. I hate deckbuilders. I literally couldnt even finish the Splatoon 3 dlc, despite being an OG WIIU fan, because I just hate the genre so much.

But this game. Something about this game. It is phenomenal. I have been chipping away at it for hours on end, just trying one step more to reach my goal of completing them all. I keep it open at work and do a battle or two as a break, I play it at home when I need to refocus myself, I play it all the time, and i have been since it came out. I reccomend this game to literally anyone, and I am genuinely going to be so sad once I finish all that I have set out to do and have to lay this game to rest, | Amazing roguelike with addicting gameplay and outstanding soundtrack.
The lucky factor can be a little anoying sometimes, but it's a dice game, so nothing wrong with it.
The gold lies on the challenges, and replaying levels when you fail does not feel bad, but engaging.
Love it. | fun little dicey game and i like the funny clown man | Incredibly fun dice-based rouge-lite.  A lot of variation in how to build each character.  Gameplay is very unique, never really played another game like it.  Love the humor in the game and soundtrack slaps.

Initially found this game as a physical board game, loved it, bought a second copy for a friend, was stoked to see there's a digital version now. Love being able to play by myself whenever. Such a cute game! And a fun challenge to master

ä½“éªŒå¤ªæœ‰æ„æ€äº†ï¼Œå½“è¿‡è­¦å±€é«˜ç®¡ä¹Ÿå½“è¿‡å…¬å¸æ€»è£ï¼Œç©·æ­»è¿‡å“æ­»è¿‡é†‰ç”Ÿæ¢¦æ­»è¿‡ï¼Œè¿˜è¢«æ‹˜è¿‡ã€‚è¿˜æ‰“ç®—å’Œæ‰€æœ‰è¿½éšè€…åˆ†åˆ«è°ˆä¸€æ¬¡æ‹çˆ±ï¼Œå¬å”¤äº†å¾ˆå¤šä¹±ä¸ƒå…«ç³Ÿçš„å¼‚ç•Œç”Ÿç‰©ï¼Œæ¢ç´¢äº†æ‰€æœ‰èƒ½æ¢ç´¢çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œæœ‰ç©ºæŠŠæ‰€æœ‰æ•™æ´¾éƒ½å»ºä¸€éï¼
æ–‡æœ¬è§‚èµæ€§å¾ˆå¼ºï¼Œéå¸¸æ´›å¼é£å‘³ï¼Œå¥½åƒï¼ | This game is a passionate love affair I keep coming back to.  It's not something I recommend to everyone (honestly I don't think any game is, but this one is more "has a highly specific target audience" than most) - you have to be some combination of a fiddly detail obsessive, wiki-diver, and opaque lore-enjoyer to really get the most out of it.  

Watching the previews will give a decent sense of the actual gameplay, which I would have difficulty describing, but the *feeling* of playing the game can't really be communicated as easily, I think.  Cultist Sim is incredibly atmospheric, and a lot better at creating interesting tension than a few gameplay clips can really convey.  The timer progression is such an integral part of not just the mechanics, but the mood.  Is your current Dream action (20 seconds remaining) going to turn up the card you need to dispel part of the Fascination counter (45 seconds remaining) currently spelling your doom?  etc.  

Also, it pays to actually read the descriptive text on things - it will all sound like pretentious bullshit at first, but there is a kind of shockingly cohesive, deep, and interesting setting and story going on, here, behind all the timer-watching.

My one main criticism is that it is really, really bad at teaching you how to play it.  I'd recommend spending a few minutes on youtube to help get the basics down; there are a lot of aspects of the game that are satisfying to find out in an exploratory manner, but the basics of stuff like, how to recruit and promote Followers are not that.  Thankfully, the fan wiki is also excellent, and basically an essential resource if you get in deep.

I really liked this farming/life sim.  The story is simple -- you have amnesia after you saved the world!  You get to learn little bits about the world, even the Dark Lord you "defeated," but there isn't very much to the story.  The characters are all charming in their own way with typical JRPG-trope personalities, but I loved all the characters. 

I would compare this game more with Animal Crossing than Stardew Valley.  Time is only moved on actions (not socialization, watering plants, and other annoying things.)  Eventually you get a pocket watch and you can give your townspeople "Groundhog Day" movie feelings.  There is flowing breeding in this game.  You also are the mayor/whatever of this town (I called myself the Supreme... of the town of Karasuno,) and you can pass "town wishes" that enhances the skills and drops. 

This game is really goes from "simple little farming, bug catching, fishing, wood/ore farming, crafting, simple card game, etc" to "I have all the power, and now ONIONS and RARE FISH fall from trees and PAPAYAS and LEGENDARY WOOD and more rare fish come from ores!!"  Every action you do early game rewards you for your hard work, and at the end of the game I would just spend my days fishing for 2 minutes and back to bed to finish the achievements.  A bit grindy, but that is expected of a farming game...

If you pick this up, don't stress like I did trying to get some magical rare fish that didn't appear for over a year.  The end game bonuses will make every single item appear.  The RNG on blueprints was also very weird, since it took me over a year to just get a bed for Ash too... but by the time I 100%'d the game, I had over a half million dewdrops (money) left and nothing to spend it on.

My other gripe is that the dev is apparently working on another game, but there's no store page at this time?  I had to dig through those "political social media" websites to find that out since I was very curious of this developer would make another game!  I wish the dev would create a Steam page for their new game, or maybe even just a newsletter on Steam using Littlewood's game, like plenty of other devs do for their upcoming game(s). 

For those curious, I married Arpeggio. I very much enjoy the hints of him being a terrible bard, even though he tries so hard with his music. | Very enjoyable at first but quickly becomes a lazy grindfest. Late achievements just require enormous amounts of mined resources but way past the point when those resources might be needed, so you're grinding for the completion rather than working toward building something cool or finishing a storyline. 

Completely runs out of steam and ideas mid-game and the rest is all just rote repetition. If it's on sale, might be worth it if you're like me and love this genre, but it's overpriced at full price imo for what feels like half a game extended by grinding rather than purpose and story. | I was looking for a game that scratched my itch for something like Dark Cloud and Dark Cloud 2 where you get to build a town and meeting certain decorative requirements can you give you rewards and upgrades. This is where this game stops being anything like DC 1 or 2 and becomes a fun desendent pf  Animal CrossingC/Stardew Valley. | Very simple, fun game. Has some Dark Cloud elements in terms of finding villagers and building your town according to their desires. Can be grindy if you decide to go for the achievements. Start breeding flowers early! | Unexpectedly, became one of my favorite games to play. I wanted to see it through until the very end. The characters are so fun to interact with and the need to explore is never satisfied. Don't miss out on this game, it is fantastic.
kids like | .

Genres: Casual, Free To Play, Indie, RPG, Simulation
Reviews: No Reviews

A short and sweet point and click game where you live the life of a Wombat. Obviously aimed at younger gamers, but this old boy still enjoyed its slow and relaxed atmosphere. The artwork and soundscape is really good, it does really remind me of the bush. Though is would nice to have music from first nations people.

Square poos are the best!

Can go from upgrading your town to slaying monsters to participating in fashion shows.

Can't say I've ever played a game that let you do that before.

[spoiler]Then again, before Graveyard Keeper I had never played a game that let you manage and run a cemetery.  These developers sure know how to inject uniqueness into their games.[/spoiler]

[h3]To be fair, the gameplay loop can get a little repetitive and at times feel too "slow" from a progression standpoint.  But since I'm such a loot goblin that part didn't really bother me all that much.  Overall, I do like this type of hero management mixed with the RPG elements and loot itemization aspects so I definitely enjoyed the time I spent with the game.[/h3] | after playing 14 hours of this game I can say this. [h2]Jugabilidad / Apartado tÃ©cnico[/h2]
Comenzamos en una isla desierta y un par de humanos. En nuestra mano tendremos una serie de cartas de diferentes tipos: recursos (plantas, Ã¡rboles y minerales), meteorologÃ­a (sol, lluvia, viento, etc), seres vivos (humanos y animales), acciones (inspeccionar y muestrear) o catÃ¡strofes (muerte y epidemia). Las cartas meteorolÃ³gicas modificarÃ¡n el entorno, creando o destruyendo distintos biomas. Los recursos generan materias primas y pueden variar segÃºn el bioma donde los usemos. Las acciones nos proporcionarÃ¡n nuevas ideas o recetas para el desarrollo de la civilizaciÃ³n, asÃ­ como el incremento de su inteligencia. Estas cartas podrÃ¡n usarse en todo momento, pero para ello necesitaremos â€œFeâ€, un elemento que obtendremos cumpliendo los deseos de nuestros colonos. Por supuesto, deberemos poner especial atenciÃ³n en recursos como el alimento, ya que si los humanos pasan hambre morirÃ¡n.
Por lo tanto, el juego consiste en usar nuestras cartas para ir creando nuevos recursos que nuestros humanos puedan emplear segÃºn su voluntad (no podemos controlarlos). Gestionar el alimento, aumentar la poblaciÃ³n, cumplir sus deseos para obtener Fe y empujarlos a que investiguen nuevas tecnologÃ­as e incrementen su intelecto, creando nuevas herramientas y edificios hasta llegar al futuro. Pero ojo, conseguir una correcta gestiÃ³n no es sencillo, siendo probable que acabemos colapsando la civilizaciÃ³n por hambre, enfermedades o falta/exceso de Fe. El juego nos ofrece ademÃ¡s dos modos: el â€œclÃ¡sicoâ€, con un numero limitado de cartas y un final, y el â€œinfinitoâ€, donde podrÃ¡s jugar hasta hartarte (o fracasar).

[h2]ValoraciÃ³n[/h2]
Simmiland es un juego tremendamente sencillo, tranquilo y gratificante de jugar, que invita a la experimentaciÃ³n y a la prueba/error. You don't need Leetcode premium when you got this game!

Also, I was banging my head against the wall before I realized you can have 2 separate solutions that each passes the size / speed check. Some levels will require you to do that. It's less about finding the best programming solution and more about gaming the system to pass the checks. | Solid programming concepts. Fun puzzles. Getting all the "stars" on each level is challenging. Humor is well-written and dark AF and on point. | Incredible game, the puzzles all around are difficult and good. 

If there is something I really love about it, is that the optional challenges to optimize the solutions can be done in very different ways so you can approach them from any angle that fits you the most depending of your style of play.

Overall, the experience with the game was very rewarding, from coming up with the most weird and ridiculous solutions to the levels, to the absolute contrast between doing tasks quick vs doing tasks in the least amount of steps.

GHB's got a distinct, cartoonish visual style, inspired by older cartoons, different upgrades, gear that can enhance stats, and a skill tree with various buffs. It's got a nice system where all the junk gear you get you can fuse into a better item, so nothing's really wasted. There's also a retirement system that resets your character to level 1 but gives you a permanent exp boost (and also skill and stat points) for the next runs. Too bad it was removed from sale, as it was a decent time waster. |  çˆ½

Simplesmente o melhor tower defense jÃ¡ inventado, segue sendo atualizado e recebendo carinho dos desenvolvedores, mesmo depois de anos de seu lanÃ§amento, e a comunidade Ã© sensacional, recomendo sempre! | This game is starting to become micro-transaction hell. It's true that they have given us numerous free updates, and with those updates we were given new towers, heroes, maps, and maybe more I don't know about. But at the same time, we are starting to get charged for what should be basic game play features or even QoL additions. The new map editor luckily lets you grind in game for it, but for new players you have to either choose a map editor you could have fun with or a hero that could help with game play. It doesn't help that both the map editor and heroes cost monkey money, which is a purchasable currency. But then there are the other examples like three times fast mode(To speed up tracks an extra tier) and even something as simple as a double cash mode. Which from what I understand only doubles in map currency, not even monkey money. The double cash mode costs $18, the triple speed mode costs $7, the game costs $14. This is not acceptable even with the amount of free content. 

Even the stuff we can get without purchasable currency is a weird daily/weekly grind. I'm talking about the trophy shop. I wish I could just grind a bunch of different options in a day, but from my experience you can only grind timed challenges that rotate and give you a reward once. This feels like a very unnecessary limit as it hinders cosmetic process for no reason. 

And now with their newest DLS, Rouge Legends. This is $10, so even double cash mode is worth more than this. But besides that, this DLC offers a new rule set, a new explore-able map(You get to explore it, not play on it), and it gives you unlock-able rouge like artifacts that change how you play the game. No new tower, no new hero, no new playable map. The fact they charge $10 for a new rule set and artifacts is ridiculous. 

It's starting to feel like they are attaching high dollar amounts to any little thing. I even had the option to purchase the new tower that came out a bit ago. But it feels like there is a cult around this game, justifying them putting high price tags on small things. Calling you stupid for even questioning price, pointing to the free things they have given us. I enjoyed this game and it is fun, and I highly appreciate the free updates, but there are so many micro transactions or a BIG amount of grind. I'd rather pay for content at a reasonable price than get free updates but seemingly random features get held until you pay more than they are worth, on top of the option to pay for just about anything in the game(New towers, more monkey money for heroes and more, random modifiers like money and speed, and even Monkey Knowledge). Not to mention, having to pay(or grind a lot) for the map editor and then having to pay even more for extra props. If then micro transactions can go down and become more fair, then I highly recommend this game. But as far as I see, it's only going to get worse. I'd recommend for new players to stay away unless they want to grind a lot or pay even more money. | The greatest tower defense game ever. Has many mechanics. Three paths available for each monkey, You need to use the monkey a lot to get it's xp and to unlock the upgrades for the monkey. Has many maps and game modes, too. Bloons TD 6 offers everything you're looking for in a Tower Defense game | I'm not liking the direction this game is taking. First, there was the double cash boost DLC, then a DLC that outright lets you skip part of the game, and now a rushed rogue-like DLC that mostly recycles assets from the base game. Modders have added better content for free. I can't recommend it right now unless NK stops with the EA-style microtransactions. | I only bought this game spontaneously when it was on a ridiculous discount. As of today, I paid approximately 1/4 of a cent per hour of playtime. It's ridiculously addictive, but in a relatively healthy way. Highly recommended for anyone who likes tower defense.

Frog Detective is a cute and VERY light "detective" game. There really isn't much of a mystery to investigate but the game encourages you to talk to all of the people on the island and meet their requests. It plays in a short amount of time and seems to be aimed at a younger audience (7+) but adults can most likely play through it in ~35 minutes.

It is a casual play and great to pull out if you want something easy and light. It is a cute game but temper your expectations of this being challenging or an active investigation type game. | A very cute and simple game. Bout 40 minutes to play though but it was a great pick up. Cant wait to join Frog Detective on more adventures | I just finished the game and it's really short. It only took about 30+ minutes but the dialogue was super funny and I loved each character even if I talked with them for 20 seconds. It's a relaxed, funny game to chill to when you're bored and wanting to play smth goofy. I gotta finish the series now | Lo adquiri con un cupon de descuento y la verdad tenia pocas o nulas expectativas del juego, pero me dio por probarlo y cambie de opiniÃ³n, es un juego bastante cortito, en menos de una hora te lo pasas y es bastante facil, pero el juego tiene un gran corazÃ³n detras, es un juego sin muchas pretenciones que no busca ser mas que un proyecto pequeÃ±o, pero aun asi tiene bastante potencial y alma, el diseÃ±o artistico es hermoso, los modelos 3D con cellshading de los personajes son bastante adorables, la historia y los dialogos tienen bastante carisma, realmente me rei mucho en algunos momentos, talvez no te vaya a dar horas de diversiÃ³n o un rato pero es un pasatiempo entretenido con bastante amor detras y eso es lo que lo hace especial para mi. | Muito bobo, claramente Ã© pra crianÃ§as, mas eu sou uma adulta de quase 19 anos e digo com toda certeza do mundo, Ã© incrÃ­vel. recomendo.

Had so much fun with Spyro!
One of the all time favorites growing up, brought back such fond memories.
If only all remake's were done like this one.
10/10 | I love Spyro, it's my favorite childhood game. But on the PC it's filled with so many problems. To list a few, you can't play it with high FPS because you can't walk, jump, or do anything. I've had my game wiped on riptos rage twice and others are having the game crash. These things should be easily fixed by the Devs but it's been left neglected. I can't recommend this game in the state. | I only ever played the original Spyro games for about 20 minutes as a kid, so I don't think this is just nostalgia talking: it's still a solid platformer from the classic era of 3-D platformers, maybe not the best series of them but still loads of fun. The game mechanics are fairly simple (jump, charge and flame, with the occasional power-up), but it keeps its fun over 3 games. The remake plays pretty smooth (one crash, one getting stuck in a wall in 30+ hours).

The game is easy to play and beat but has some difficulty spikes, particularly with some of the mini-games. The games, especially the third one, suffered from the era's need to include every type of popular game as a mini-game. If I wanted to skateboard I'd go play Tony Hawk! *old man shouts at clouds* | Unfortunately, I cannot finish the game because the camera keeps malfunctioning and pointing in arbitrary directions. I wish they would fix this. | I like what I've seen so far. This game has nice graphics that run pretty well even on Ryzen 5600G integrated graphics. (720p with a mixture of high/ultra settings). I am also impressed by the quality of the dragons' animations. It seems like a lot of care and passion went into these remakes.

A fun party game for me and my friends! I enjoy the games within this pack and they make for good and silly times! Trivia Murder Party 2 is one of my favorites due to the many minigames and easter eggs, its very entertaining and replayable! The other games also have a lot of content that makes it fun to play with other people. My favorite to play with friends is Push The Button, its quite replayable too!! The other games I'm neutral on, but they're still good! I would recommend this party pack!! ^-^ | This game is so great, I play this game with my friend group every time that we hang out, and it is truly the best game to play with friends. This is my favorite party pack (I have 4,5,6, and 10), and I especially love the trivia murder party and push the button games. Highly recommend for anyone trying to find a game to play with their friends. | Don't get me wrong, trivia murder party is a decent game, and joke boat can be great with the right participants, however, this just happens so rarely that I can't recommend this pack. Many of the games in it are just extremely bland. but I do find myself coming back to those two games in particular every now and then.

I take it back, I hadn't tried push the button or role models and admittedly role models isn't good but push the button is amazing. | This is the best Jackbox Party Pack. Trivia Murder Party 2 alone makes this pack worth it. | One of the best, well rounded Jackbox Party Packs, right next to 3 and 7

The dialog isn't actually skippable and most of the game so far has been watching this old man walk around slowly while you click on things for him to clean. Why is that such a large and slow part of this game? | I purchased both the Tenants and the DLC, Pets. Gameplay is fun if a bit repetitive after a while. Mostly designing and decorating small apartments, to earn money to purchase your own, to fix up and rent out. I like that aspect. The decorating seems to place an emphasis on decorating and using small objects to enhance the "lived in" feel of a home. For example adding toilet paper, a plunger, and toilet brush to every toilet, or books to bookshelves. I find myself playing for an hour or two at a time before moving on. 

I do regret buying the DLC and would not recommend it. Pets adds tasks which are more annoying than fun, like searching the entire slum for 10 stunned and dazed parrots, or figuring out how to use the mouse to "stroke" a lost pet, fix their leg, and then try to get them adopted. Meh, I could deal with less direct interaction for the pets. I do like that the tenants can have pets but in early game, when the apartments are small and cramped, there is very little room to add items pets need. | The Tenants is chaotic, fun, and strangely addictive. Itâ€™s a love-hate relationship simulator with your tenants, and honestly, thatâ€™s what makes it shine. Where you get to live out your dream of being a landlord without the real-world headaches of broken boilers, angry phone calls, or tenants "forgetting" to pay rent. Instead, you get a charming, oddly addictive sim that makes property management feel... fun?

10/10, would renovate another bathroom only for my tenant to complain that itâ€™s "too shiny." | it just isnt that good. maybe i didnt give it enough time? i like sims
i like big ambitions.
why wouldnt i like this?
if you want a Simulator that you can be a relator, play the sims 4 with the rent dlc. | honestly i've enjoyed it. it might not be for everyone but i think its fun.

[h2] ISLANDERS â€“ minimalism, tranquility, and strategic thinking! [/h2]
[h3] Personal experience: [/h3]
I spent over 5 hours in the game, and I can confidently say that itâ€™s perfect for those looking to unwind and relax. The simplicity and minimalism of the game are top-notch. At first, I was surprised by how such a simple mechanic could be so captivating. Slowly, I started building islands, exploring their potential, and genuinely enjoying the process.
The game is a perfect way to relax. Thereâ€™s no pressure; you simply build, develop, and enjoy the view. I found the way ecosystems come to life and how the island transforms into a vibrant world incredibly satisfying.
[h3] Pros and cons: [/h3]
[b] Pros: [/b]
[list]
[*] Minimalist style: The visuals are light and pleasant, not overwhelming, yet still visually appealing.
[*] Easy to learn: The gameplay is simple to grasp, but itâ€™s addictive and hard to stop playing.
[*] Calming and atmospheric: Perfect for those who want to relax and disconnect from the world.
[*] Building process: Watching your island grow and develop is a deeply immersive experience.
[/list]
[b] Cons: [/b]
[list]
[*] Limited content: The game can feel a bit repetitive over time, and while it leaves a good impression, you may crave more variety in mechanics.
[*] Lack of challenge: For those who prefer dynamic gameplay, the game might feel too laid-back and lacking in competitive elements.
[*] Short experience: Some players might find the game to be a bit too short and simple after a few hours.
[/list]
[h3] Result: [/h3]
ISLANDERS is an excellent game for those who appreciate a relaxing experience and want a break from intense projects. Despite its simplicity, itâ€™s surprisingly addictive and allows you to create beautiful islands. If you enjoy calm gameplay and donâ€™t mind a short but enjoyable experience, this game is definitely for you!
[b] My rating: 8/10 [/b]
[i] I recommend it to anyone whoâ€™s looking for a peaceful, laid-back experience without expecting complex mechanics. [/i] | One of the most brilliant games I've played. I've gotten so much play out of this "casual" city builder. It can absolutely be a casual game if you want it to be, but if you want to maximize your score then this game is actually quite deep. And it's deep with simple systems, which makes it way more accessible. You place buildings, they get points based on their proximity to other buildings, and you need to score points to unlock the next pack of semi-random buildings. That's it, that's the game. What this does is create a game where you're trying to balance placing buildings in the highest scoring way with your need to score points right now, so that you may unlock the buildings you need to make the highest scoring plays. When you can place anything anywhere, this creates quite a complex puzzle. My only complaint is that some of the high scores on the leaderboard are obviously fake due to a glitch from years ago, and they should really be wiped. | [u][b]ISLANDERS[/b][/u] is a serene and tranquil procedurally-generated, endless, score-based puzzle game which has a city-building theme to it. Although its tagline states that it is "A minimalist city builder," this is slightly misleading because the city-building aspect is moreso an aesthetic rather than a core identity of the gameplay since it doesn't involve resource or population management like the more traditional city-building games and is also less predictable due to the randomness of the maps and some of the building layouts.

Overall, I recommend the game as it is very relaxing to play casually for an hour or two here and there, while simultaneously having just enough depth to satiate score-chasers, and the procedural generation of the maps constantly challenges you to adapt to the random terrain and natural features that you are provided. Although I don't care to compete for high scores, I found that attempting to optimize my cities was unexpectedly fun and especially gratifying after planning the general layout of my city and watching the points come flooding in as my plan came to fruition.

Note: this review is current as of the unnumbered patch released on 23 November 2023 which is the latest update.

[hr][/hr]
[quote][b]S U M M A R Y[/b][/quote]

- The gameplay is very accessible to a wide range of players as it is simple and intuitive enough for casual players, yet also has enough depth to challenge score-chasers, but the game is very minimalistic and offers little to no precision when it comes to building an efficient and aesthetically-pleasing city;
- The replay value is decent and the game is fun when played occasionally in shorter sessions but the core gameplay loop will get repetitive very quickly;
- The graphics are vibrant, almost cartoonish, and are reminiscent of the "Chibi" art style;
- The soundtrack is composed of relaxing ambient music with rural-style sound effects to give the feeling of an authentic city; and
- There is no story whatsoever but a casual puzzle game like this doesn't have a need for one.

[hr][/hr]
[quote][b]A C H I E V E M E N T S[/b][/quote]

The game has 38 achievements, most of which will be acquired throughout casual gameplay while a few will require you to go out of your way to set them up but aren't difficult by any means and should take less than 10 hours to achieve; however, the [i]Conqueror[/i] achievement will take at least 30 hours by itself and require you to become very familiar with the mechanics of the game while also planning the general layout of each map before placing any buildings. That being said, it isn't nearly as RNG-dependent as many complaints on the Steam Discussion forums would lead you to believe as you merely have to invest some time into the game to learn it beyond a casual level since the achievement is not a given whatsoever.

[hr][/hr]
[quote][b]R E V I E W[/b][/quote]

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
The gameplay is more akin to a puzzle game rather than a traditional city builder because of its focus on simplicity and minimalism: a map is procedurally-generated, you are given a choice between two random sets of buildings, and your inventory is populated with a number of buildings from the chosen set. Your goal is to place the buildings efficiently in order to receive point bonuses from other types of buildings and meet the point threshold which gives you another choice between two more random sets of buildings. This process repeats itself until you either fail to meet the point threshold, by having no more buildings to place, or meet the threshold which allows you to travel to the next map and restart the gameplay loop, ad infinitum.

As far as casual play is concerned, the game is simple and intuitive enough to get into and occasionally have fun with in small spurts. Unfortunately, the same can't be said for those who like to chase high scores because the game demands absolute precision when placing buildings and planning out your city but offers you very few tools to facilitate this need and the tools that do exist are quite shoddy. For example, there is somewhat of an integrated "snap-to" ability but it is finnicky and rarely lines up buildings perfectly with one another which can lead to inefficiencies and cause you to lose points -- and sometimes those few points could be the difference between losing a run altogether or proceeding to the next map.

Sometime between 2019 and 2022, the game was handed over to an entirely new development team and they added the more difficult achievements which require a certain level of precision that the game simply can't offer and this makes the minimalist approach of the game feel almost incongruous with, and somewhat inadequate for, these new achievements (one of which is the infamous [i]Conqueror[/i] achievement). If they had made the existing snapping more accurate, added an option to turn on a grid, or gave you a laser level tool, then the game would be feel much more precise but you can definitely tell the difference between the two development teams' philosophy on achievements.

Another minor gripe that I have with the overly-minimalist approach is that the House, Mansion, and Park buildings also have a variety of different layouts (similar to Tetris blocks) but the next one is randomly chosen for you and can't be changed which is irritating from an efficiency perspective and true city-building aspect but I can't complain too much about it because it fits the minimalist design approach that they were going for.

Nevertheless, I still found it quite fun to learn the more intricate nuances to the game's mechanics and optimize my cities; however, once I figured out the most efficient setup then the most fun part became the planning of the city and playing the actual game for long periods of time became a bit of a chore which is why I think that it's a good game to occasionally have fun with in smaller doses because it gets repetitive very quickly.

The game also has a Sandbox Mode where you can unleash your creative side  with an unlimited supply of all buildings and a Photo Mode where you can take fancy images of said creations using a variety of built-in filters and tools.

[h3]Graphics[/h3]
The graphics are vibrant and almost cartoonish in nature which gives it a very charming look. The buildings are also blocky but in a cute and bubbly sort of way -- if anything, I'd say that its art style actually resembles the popular "Chibi" art style because of how cute, minimalistic, and caricature-like the art design is. The second development team also added a number of optional seasonal and holiday themes that you can apply to your game to spruce things up at your whim which is a nice touch.

[h3]Sound[/h3]
The soundtrack is made up of relaxing ambient music with scenic noises such as dogs barking, birds chirping, and other rural sound effects. The music is so modest that I'm not even sure if the audio tracks would count as "songs". Much like the graphics, there are a number of optional seasonal and holiday-themed songs that you can enable or disable but I frankly couldn't even tell the difference between any of the songs. All-in-all, it's just a very relaxing soundtrack which I would say resembles white noise to some degree. The sound effects are few and far between but the main one you will hear is placing a building which makes a very satisfying plopping sound.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Overall, I recommend the game because you can easily relax to it for an hour and forget about the stressors of life as you get immersed in its soothing audio, charming visuals, and straightforward and leisurely nature. If you're more of a score-chaser then it's surprisingly fun and engaging to plan out your city, optimize the placement of your buildings, and get that feeling of elation as your plan flourishes and you watch your points soar. | ISLANDERS is a beautifully minimalist city-building game thatâ€™s perfect for relaxing and flexing your creativity. The simple mechanics focus on strategic placement of buildings, offering a satisfying mix of puzzle and strategy elements. The colorful, procedurally generated islands are gorgeous, and each new map feels like a fresh canvas for your ideas.

While the game doesnâ€™t offer endless depth or complexity, its simplicity is part of its charm. Itâ€™s great for short sessions or unwinding after a long day. For its price, itâ€™s an excellent indie gem and a must-play for fans of chill city builders. | ĞœĞ°Ğ»ĞµĞ½ÑŒĞºĞ°Ñ, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸ Ğ¼ĞµĞ´Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ½Ğ°Ñ. That said, I'm finally leaving a review to try and balance out the overblown reaction to Krafton's involvement.

Fair's fair, the announcement was very opaque and poorly handled. On Steam. Out of nowhere there's a news update about personal information transfer, suddenly invoking the name of a new company instead of clarifying that, "Hey, Dinkum has a publisher to take care of some of the overhead now!" It's made much clearer on Discord what is actually going on, for those like me who might have had their hackles raised by the announcement. Here are the important points you're looking for:

- Krafton is now the game's publisher. They will be handling the game's socials (Discord, YouTube, etc.), though not exclusively; there will be additional language support; and perhaps some future benefits, we'll see.
- Krafton will be receiving about as much user data as James had to begin with; which is to say, whatever Steam shares with any publishers and anyone you've ever bought something from on Steam before. We're not talking about a game that had any invasive telemetry to begin with, here.
- James Bendon is still the developer. He has not [i]passed the reins on[/i] to anyone else.

So if you are for some reason EXTREMELY OPPOSED to a bog standard publisher based in South Korea having access to the most innocuous level of data (i.e. the fact that you own the game, and what account the ownership is attached to) then perhaps you have cause for concern. Otherwise, this is just a poorly-communicated and completely unremarkable revelation that the game now has a publisher and is going to be getting more language support. | As you can see, a lot of hours into this game. I began my journey with this game back when it first started as a little mobile project. As someone who always plays Minecraft in creative mode, I was immediately interested. It had a fun concept, beautiful visuals, decent interface, and constant updates. I think the updates were the best part early on. There were usually lots of new items making each update feel like an early Christmas. What really impressed me was the care the developers took to read people's reviews, respond, and actually implement a large portion of the (unsolicited) suggestions. I've seen very few developers who care that much about player feedback.

Unfortunately, the mobile version suffers a bit from mild performance issues and fairly constant crashing (although I'd be more that willing to blame all of that on my 6-year-old iPhone), so I was overjoyed to learn this lovely little game was getting a PC release. I bought it the day it went early access and have been having a blast with it since.

Some of the awesome things that most stood out to me when I first played the PC version:
- It has all the same visuals and UI as the mobile version, but it manages to look just as clear and pleasant on my PC monitor
- All the worlds I started on the Mobile are compatible with this version
- I have keyboard shortcuts now!
- There is even more freedom cooked into the build process with the freeform mode, so you're no longer restricted to a grid

Some things that get the tiniest bit annoying:
- You have to click and drag to move across your world; no keyboard navigation
- No bulk build, especially for land formations
- People who insist that it must have structure to be fun

These developers have gained my trust and I fully expect this already satisfying experience to improve over time. | ==ä¿®æ”¹äº2019.10.22==

å¸Œæœ›åç»­æ›´æ–°èƒ½ç»§ç»­å®Œå–„å„ç§åŠŸèƒ½ | Just have to say WOW, This game has improved well in the short time since I started playing it on mobile. I recommend this game to anyone who likes a game with no direct point and total freedom on the sandbox aspect of the game. I wish there were more things to spend money on and less of the stuff was free. I like an incentive along with my relaxed building game play. But for early release I give this game 15/10 =) | Now that I'd had time to sit on it, I'm going to give you a proper review on why you should give this game a definite pass. I'll be leaving my original review at the bottom for posterity but get ready to get down and technical on why this game deserves a negative review. 

This game is a port of the mobile game Pocket Build onto Steam. I'm going to talk about it a lot because to know Super Build is to know Pocket Build, as they are functionally identical except in certain cases.

Super Build costs $15 on Steam when not on sale. We thought it might be because the Steam version has all the items unlocked but no, the mobile game also has a $13 a month subscription fee. Point is, this game is not worth that amount of money.

The Saturation on Super Build is absolutely horrendous. It looks a lot better on Mobile because again, it's a mobile port. It was in no way balanced for PCs. Turning it down makes everything muddied and too hard to make out while turning it high makes everything deep fried. There is no good range on the saturation. It may burn out your screen if played too long.

The game has two modes, currently. Survival Sandbox and Ultimate Sandbox.

Survival Sandbox is that in name only. It's more of a Resources Needed mode. To build anything requires food and wood. You get food and wood by commanding your villagers to harvest it. Its only sandbox in that you have access to all the items right away rather than unlocking them through lengthy gameplay and can place them wherever.

Ultimate Sandbox is the actual free build sandbox mode. You can build to your heart's content, within reason. The game does have better controls on PC than Mobile for building. However, a lot of items are not labeled for what they are. A chunk of items are labeled which makes it feel a bit lazy.

You'll notice some items have a lock icon on them but if you try and use them, you can use them just fine. The reason for this is they're locked on the Mobile game. They were too lazy to remove the lock icons when porting the game over.

I said it currently has two game modes. That is because, for some god awful reason, there is a planned Zombie battle mode. Yes, you'll be able to fight zombies in a peaceful sandbox building game. Thats not a Minecraft dig, that's me pointing out how stupidly out of place a Zombie mode would be.

You might ask how I know about that. Where does it say that? That's because their project roadmap is only available in game. It's nowhere on the Steam page as you've seen by now and the devs are woefully closed lipped on everything. Steam hasn't had a news update since December last year but the game has seen an update. Just not on Steam.

Cross-Play. There is no actual functioning cross-play. This is what got me, I saw cross-play and wanted to see what the mobile was like. If you play on mobile, you will lock yourself out of anything on PC. That build you spent hours on? You can no longer access it. Why? Because your game isn't up to date.

Now you get into the issue of being a mobile port. Because Pocket Build is the original game, it gets all content updates first. This means that the PC and Mobile versions are not synced in terms of updates so if you play the mobile version, which does *not* warn you of this fact, you will no longer be able to open anything back up on the PC version.

And it's absolutely not stated anywhere that this is the case, you get no warning boxes, no nothing. I was unaware the mobile game was even updated ahead of PC until I had to dig into it to find out what the hell was up!

Also, turns out the Mobile in-game currency is still in the Steam version, you just can't see it. And all the items that take it aren't active in Steam either. But if you do manage to get them, you're going to be paying by the barrel. Literally, thats what they call their in-game currency. And its not a one time thing to unlock them, you pay per piece you place.

Multiplayer. Since no one else I know owns this game and definitely won't now, I can't give a definitive answer on what's up with that. I will say that again, this is mean to just be a peaceful building game. Multiplayer serves zero purpose in the context of that.

It really feels like the devs are falling prey to losing the identity of this game and scope creep. They have a lot of things they want to add and a lot of things that aren't needed. This is a game that lets you build little towns. It does not need a first person view, a multiplayer mode, a combat/war mode, a zombie battle mode. These are all things either in the game or planned to be in the game, I'm not making any of those up.

They take ideas from the community but don't look further than 'oh the community wants this' at how it will affect their game.

At it's foundation, this game has a lot of potential, it really does. It does what it set out to do well. But between devs who can't communicate to their players and a mobile version that will always come first, I can not in any way, shape, or form, recommend anyone to buy or play this game.

If you still want to buy it even after this, wait until it's on sale. There is nothing here worth $15

Sometimes all you want from a game is to sit down, relax, and embark on an adventure into an unknown world, Alluris satisfies that desire perfectly. Its varied and beautiful landscapes have me excited to stumble upon the next environment and experience the unusual events, people, and quests it has to offer. The way you make decisions is all based on swiping either left or right on the card presented. Then you are offered two choices of how to proceed with the given situation. It's a very simple mechanic but the game is still able to take you on unique quests and form a story around the world you're exploring. I found myself sucked into an almost never ending session as I told myself "one more swipe" to see what the next day had in store for me. Highly recommended. | Really fun game! Quite a diverse story line which can be played in different ways as you unlock new characters.

I don't like how you have a limit of 500 days, and the game doesn't tell you that, also when you taken 'side quests' there isn't a log so if you get distracted you can forget what you were doing. An explanation on what Karma does would be nice too!

Having said that I would still highly recommend the game for anyone who likes these sorts of card decision games, like reign. | My problem: nerd that loves DnD but has no friends to play with.
Solution: Alluris.
10/10 would recommend. | So I definitely get on a lot better with this than the usual swipey Realms type game. Once you figure out how the basic mechanics work you can make PLANS much more easily and actually have a trajectory. Nothing's guaranteed of course since the right cards might not come up or an unexpected interaction might shunt you somewhere else, but you can generally have the idea of "I want to do THIS this time" and actually go do it.

Only my second character or so was already a pirate captain who married a noble prince, built a house in Atlantis, developed magical powers, adopted a Tiefling child, etc.

There is going to be some trial and error as you figure out what choices lead to what, so if you're one of the people who hates that, skip. But if you're tickled by "Wow, the bear cub I found in the forest is now my riding steed and because of that the barbarian king thinks I am super cool and let me lick his power stone which gave me super-strength" then enjoy. | Alluris is a fantasy adventure game based around cards which present two choices to the player, swiping left or right, to progress.  There is no deck building, but you do build a character through the RPG elements and can acquire different followers and items throughout the quest.  The first run will feature a human peasant as the protagonist, but the world can be experienced again as a hero of a different race or background once unlocked.  Likely you wonâ€™t complete the broader story about stopping an evil overlord within a time limit, which each card swipe representing one day of the adventure, on the first attempt, but you can uncover more quest threads with each attempt and unlock character backgrounds that make starting out easier and the game replayable.  Once you know how to approach different side quests and minibosses you can do the same thing on a later game, but possessing certain items or having certain attributes, which you gain in various ways or start with based on your background, sometimes opens up creative approaches.  A main road through the kingdom acts as a central hub to journey into the different biomes, most of which have a deeper biome such as the forest leading to the deepwoods.  Finding the area you want to adventure in from the main road can sometimes be a timewaster since you might have to keep swiping left to carry on until the location card youâ€™re interested in appears.  I was impressed with the gameâ€™s depth, when it first seems like you just swipe right to fight things, and found it reasonably priced for the experience.

Absolutely beautiful art and design. Pretty decent game-play and a captivating story/world.

Also cute talking frog. 

There are a few moments where dialogue does not match text, but that's rare and does not detract from the game-play. 

 | Just a really good story. Made me sad, happy and angry at times. Loved it. | I admit I don't have too much experience or interest in RPGs but I had a lot of fun with this one both for the gameplay, and characters and story!

I liked it from early on but waited to finish it to leave a proper view and I can't say it lost my interest ever! The different strategies you can use with the different combinations of the characters is really fun. I loved exploring the world and the characters were so cute! The art style was very pretty and what caught my attention in the first place. It being fully voiced also a nice luxury, features some of my favorite actors too!

I def think it's worthy of a try! I was lucky enough to get it while it was on sale but I think it's well worth it's full price.

very fun, slow start but when it picks up its good. | Love this game it's fun but can get grindy and confusing at times

A very well-written game. I hope anyone that enjoys stories where you get to make some tough decisions gives this game a try. The game has the same vibe as a TellTale game, but with the difference being there is a clear GOOD and BAD ending to this game. 

Checklist:

Music: Really good. BGM is easy to listen to, and the welsh/celtic rock song for the credits and main menu is very fun to listen to. 

Character design: Pretty good for pixels. I could tell the difference between almost every npc, and the character splash art at the end of the end felt very modern. 

Aesthetic: I really enjoy the style. It's very clean pixel art. It's not common to see games in this style so it was a refreshing take on art and game design. 

Accessibility: You need to be someone who enjoys reading a lot of text, as a large majority of the game is comprised of reading character dialogue. There is no voice overs, just some mumbled gibberish. 

Game difficulty: Pretty easy. The first few weeks seem like there are some tough choices, but you learn pretty quick to listen to the petitioner speaking to your King character about their plight and needs. Depending on how they sound when they ask for help, you can tell right away if you should actually give them aid, or call them out on their bull crap. 

Multiple playthroughs: Kinda. This game is only best played by doing two routes. Good route, or bad route. There isn't multiple endings aside from doing things the ethically right way, or the morally corrupt way. 

Price Point: I was gifted the game, so I don't know how expensive it is in the store. But if it's anything under $25 USD, then it's a pretty fair price point. I would still recommend buying it at a sale price though, for the sole fact that the game is REALLY short. You'll do an entire play through in about 6 hours. Maybe less if you're not too worried about your choices and the impact of your choices. 

Cons:
There's only one thing that really bugged me during the entire game. There is a pretty clear situation that pops up pretty early on that you (the player) probably would never agree to do. However, the situation is written into the story and isn't actually a choice the player can make. Long story short, I didn't enjoy being locked out of a choice that I would never have made myself, but unfortunately, it's just part of the story. One of those times where what the player expects from a Kingdom Management Sim RPG and what the narrator (or game dev) intended don't really align. I don't see the game devs as bad people for this forced choice, but at the end of the day, I still I wish I could've completely avoided the literal main plot of the game. 

Overall: The game is great. Definitely consider picking it up if you like a gripping story. Absolutely beautiful art style that does not give away the punishing gameplay. In As Far As The Eye, you play as the wind, guiding a nomadic tribe to safe land. I very much enjoy the different take on the resource-management genre, with the journey broken up into multiple halts and obstacles. The short-term goal is simply to make it to the next halt before the step counter runs out and the flood arrives. The non-combative gameplay focuses on harvesting different resources instead, and actually provides a decent goal-oriented focus within which to use them.

Since each halt is procedurally generated, with varying amounts of ressources available, planning the journey ahead is essential for a realistic chance of making it to The Eye. Resources must be carefully managed, since they are simultaneously needed for the journey and the progression of the tribe per halt. At the beginning, I often struggled with rations and faced starvation among my Pupils. Only after many hours spent figuring out the mechanics, the gameplay finally started to feel fair. The challenge lies clearly in the fact that mistakes canâ€™t be undone, with the single save file being overridden every turn.

Overall, I enjoy the simplicity of the gameplay, setting up camp over and over again, strategically placing buildings, and managing resources. The task-based progression of the tribe fosters a sense of attachment to the success of the Pupils. And I particularly love seeing them shapeshift into animal spirits based on their assigned trades. Although limited, the lore of As Far As The Eye fits seamlessly with the gameplay mechanics. This even makes me appreciate that excess resources gathered and left behind count against the final score, since the Pupils live in harmony with nature. | 6.5/10 - Decent

Buy on sale.  Worth the campaign and a run or two.  I can't remember how much I paid for it but about $10 CAD feels reasonable.

Really cute game.  Pretty decent challenge and strategy.  Satisfying to play once you learn.

Tip: 1. Start training a druid early.  2. If you can't find your pupils, look for their balloons.

If I had anything interesting to say, it would be that the bottlenecks between halts serve to really narrow my focus.  I'm not talking about the requirements to reach a halt, I'm talking about the inventory bottlenecks to reach it.  I found myself caring less and less about my pupils, their really cool skill trees, and what capabilities I could unlock, because I would likely need to throw away resources anyway to make room for food and the one mobile building I threw together.  It's really hard to get extraction up and running without a good supply of food for the beginning of each halt.  But the amount of food that requires takes up most of your caravan's inventory, making it hard to build anything right out of the gate.  
If I could change one small thing that would make the game significantly better, it would be to double the amount of food per stack in the caravan's inventory.  That would open up way more possibilities for interesting choices per run on what buildings to make mobile and what resources to take with you. | nicely done city builder in turn based | æ°›å›´æ„Ÿæ‹‰æ»¡äº†

I still want to like this game. It's not that it could have been so much more, it's not that the 4x and combat elements are still too disconnected. It's quite simply that the actual gameplay is not fun. 
The case study that prompted me to write this review:
I'm playing a greedy game where I'm the only civ on my relatively large continent. I pick England and build Strongholds in various strategic locations. I own the whole continent and have lots of tech and buildings but a fairly small army - just enough to strongly defend a single attack point. I begin building ships to explore the world. I finally encounter another civ, then another. The world congress begins almost immediately. One of the civs demands 2000 gold from me. I naturally refuse. They push the issue to congress. I don't have an embassy yet, so I can't do anything about that, but fine. They won't be able to break into my continent. They pillage one of my two harbors. This gives them enough warscore to enforce peace, get the 2000 gold plus another 2400 gold for war reparations. I'm in bankruptcy. I work my way out of it. They demand 2000 gold again and now I can't refuse because my people don't want war.
What is the gameplay here? Pillaging a single district is enough to instantly end a war and enforce demands strong enough to cripple the enemy until you can immediately send more demands and declare war again? The war didn't even last long enough for me to attempt to fight it. I wouldn't mind if they enforced demands after they had landed a force and begun sieging my cities or thoroughly pillaged my entire coastline, but it was one single district. Honestly most games seem to end with one stupid mistake or lucky break, which is already not that fun, but you throw mechanics like that in and it just isn't worth trying anymore. | å¥½å¥½å¥½ï¼Œä»Šå¤©æ˜¯2025å¹´2æœˆ7å·ï¼Œé‚£è¾¹æ–‡æ˜7å‘å”®ï¼ŒEpicå°±æŠŠäººç±»å…è´¹é€äº†æ˜¯å§ã€‚ | I love this game. This is the best game I have ever played!

The story, the graphics, the art, the music... everything is incredible.

I have replayed the game (you're meant to play it more than once!) more than 20 times, and I am really close to achieving ALL possible endings. The first run WILL break your heart in the best way possible, and will make you want to play again and again until you reach your perfect ending.
No run is overly similar to the others in my opinion, as you can always find out one more detail about a character, or unlock one more dialogue you hadn't seen before.

The card game is very cool, but does not affect the storyline too much (unless you put in in hard mode), but if you don't like it there is the possibility to skip them completely.

There are different characters that you can befriend and/or romance (romance is not mandatory), each with their quirks, flaws and individual backstory. I think no character is too "perfect", too "good" or too "bad", as there is always some perspective from which they can seem the opposite. Through these characters, the game explores themes, such as love, loss, unhealthy obsession, mental health and abuse. However, although the themes are heavy, it is not felt throughout the game, and the playthrough remains pleasant, yet makes you reflect a lot.

Moreover, unlike many other games, almost EVERY SINGLE CHOICE you make will somehow affect the story you get. With a single conversation you can save or break someone, but not to worry, if you don't get what you want, you can always play again and make it better.

Last but not least, the music. The music is absolutely incredible, and the only song with lyrics from the game (you'll know when you hear it!) was among my Top 5 listens in 2024. The soundtrack is paired flawlessly to the scenes in the game, and makes the moments much more immersive.

This game means so much to me, it changed my life I could even say. So do yourself a favour and play it. | On the downside, I personally found this game a bit twee and heavy handed. That said, I liked it enough to play multiple times through. While I found the characters to be more like caricatures, the art is beautiful, the soundtrack is lovely, and the setting and gameplay are unique and interesting. It's definitely a good choice for a mild, comfort game. | It's so amazing. Out of most of the visual novel-esque, and choice heavy story games ive played. I'd say this one is probably the best, so much can change based on your choices and all the characters are so well written and interesting, even the ones that you'd think are just annoying. 
The game definitely goes places too, it never got boring and i was excited the whole time. Even the setting itself is super interesting and just fun to learn about. There is also a small addition of almost balatro like card challenges. Making straights and flushes and using the memories from choices you make as cards to succeed or fail at things. Its almost a roguelike with all the different cards you can get. I think this small bit of gameplay really helps round out the experience, it prevents it from being just one big book that you sit there and read for hours, it helps break up the reading with a little gameplay other than choices. The game is definitely better for it. | i love this game so much it is so replayable i see something new still every run and ive played like 6 lives | I don't know how to feel about this game. I wish Steam did starred reviews and not just Yes or No.

On the plus side, this is a beautiful game, with a really unique story, some of the most weirdly deep worldbuilding for a game in its genre (did not expect that at all!), and a gorgeous art style. The gameplay loop is fun and relaxing, and I really enjoyed playing it. It's fun watching your friends grow up around you, the story gets surprisingly serious at times, the choices you make do actually matter, and it has a lot of replay value. It's got some interesting takes on common scifi ideas, like a living planet, psionic aliens, nonlinear time, and the dangers of fascist ideology taking over a space colony. The worldbuilding is really cool, and the ecosystem is thought out in a kind of mindblowing amount of detail.

However.... some of the writing choices are awkward, clunky, and strange. I'm assuming the target audience are teenagers, so a lot of was easy to ignore as just "this was not written for me," but there are two things that sat really uncomfortably.

First, you can totally customize your character's sexuality and gender identity, including being a bioengineered genetic experiment, but you cannot be intersex, and that feels kind of bad when the rest of the game has ticked all of the representation boxes. The "I" in LGBTQIA does not exist in I Was a Teenage Exocolonist, but everything else does, so... It really sticks out, and feels like the creators were just trying to tick boxes to market the game better to teenagers. I tried to wave it away as part of the critique - the game subtly implies a few times that your parents are consciously rebelling against the planned breeding programs of the colony mindset - but then my colonist got older.

So, when you're about 16 (and maybe the option exists earlier than this, not sure), you start getting the option to flirt with grown adults. Notably, Utopia, the chief scavenger. It's a truly strange writing choice that only gets worse once you meet Sym. While I'm pretty sure you can only meet Sym once you're an adult, Sym is a very old alien who has been watching you since you were a little kid, protecting you the entire time you were growing up, has been intruding in your mind via psychic dreams, and from the moment you meet Sym the game tries to railroad you into a speed romance. I think it's for dramatics, because they die immediately, but it's still extremely uncomfortable given Sym is not the only adult with romance dialogue. Real, human writers made this game and chose to let your teen try to romance adults who watched them grow up from a little kid. It's not great. The only upside is that you are thankfully not forced to click on these options.

I don't hate the ending as much as most of the reviewers do. I think meeting your astral self after death is a nice poetic moment and a bit of fourth wall breaking to allude to the game's replayability. You're meant to replay this game a few times, and that's what the dialogue is about. I'm looking forward to trying to get different outcomes.

I just wish that I could give this game 3 or 4 stars instead of a single yes or no. If you like dating sims, this will probably be fun until the end, because none of the romances as far as I can tell actually work out in the end. I just wanted to play a fun scifi story game with pretty artwork and didn't care about that much, so this delivered that. If I had a teen, I'd probably recommend this game to them, because it seems like a fun way to explore your identity and learn about its ideas and themes. But it also makes me uncomfortable, and not in the "empowered to fight fascism" way that the game developers probably intended. I'm sure that some teen will really enjoy playing this game and seeing themselves in the characters, but I'm not sure it works for me.

... Also, it's just kind of cruel that the character who spends her entire childhood talking about how much she hates that she's being groomed by the adults around her to be a babymaker one day (Nem) ends up in an abusive marriage as an adult. I get that it's probably supposed to be commentary but it just feels meanspirited? If this is going to bother you, you probably shouldn't pick up this game, because I'm unclear on if you can prevent this ending.

I bought my copy tonight and played the tutorial and a full game against the AI. I think there are some opportunities for DAISU but overall the gameplay itself is solid.

Opportunities:
- Tiles could be clearer on zoom in. I like that the text is there, but I want to explore the art on those tiles too. I want a button to do a big zoom like I can do on Tabletop Simulator or Tabletopia.
- The tutorial has text that cannot be sped up and it doesn't always fit in the text bubble. That needs to be a) easily skippable and b) fit in the text bubble. I know you need to read the text, but you shouldn't be guessing how fast I can read. I can read much faster than the "next" text arrow appears.
- Play Local has New Game and Tutorial buttons that appear to be greyed out, but they aren't. And you're supposed to click them.
- When playing with AI, you can't see what your partner drew/chose for use in your castle, so you can't synergize with them. This led to me making decisions for my castle in a vacuum.
- I finished the second tutorial, but it never acknowledged I finished it. It just wouldn't accept feedback anymore and I had to hit escape and 'exit' to go back to the menu.
- Music sometimes behaves odd. Leaving the tutorial to the main menu made the music abruptly stop and then go to a new music track. Perhaps a fade out and fade in would be less jarring.
- The green "Ok" or select button is an odd design choice, it doesn't feel like it matches the same aesthetic of the rest of the game, but I find myself punching the spacebar to accept my changes anyway. It's not a real big deal.

All of that said, I really enjoyed my time with BTCoMKL. The beta was ROUGH on my PC, it was very choppy, very jerky, this has been completely resolved. It runs so quick and it says all settings are on Epic despite me not having a gaming laptop at all. It's a cheap Dell my father-in-law bought that I put a SSD in.
Everything I love about BTCoMKL is still here in the PC version except for the plotting and planning with my partner. BUT it did feel significantly better to crap on one of my castles to try and take the lead from the AI who had the lead.

I like how quick the gameplay was. It was a delight. I hope the online lobby picks up. I think the price for the game was fair too. Of course I always find myself wanting to wait for a Steam sale but I'm not much of a PC gamer, so I typically have no problem waiting. That said, I don't regret not waiting. Congratulations Team Daisu.

Oh, one more item of delight I wanted to mention.. I love how adding tiles to the castle actually causes the castle to grow behind you. You see walls come up and towers rise. It's a very neat effect that made me smile a couple of times. Also, great job identifying the castles by color. That made it very easy to identify which castle I was working with. | Actually, the only way I would play this game is through this app: unlike the board game, this digital version permanently displays your and your opponents' score throughout the entire game.  In the board game you had no idea how well you or your opponents are doing, except until the very end.  This digital version totally solves that.  I own the physical game, but I will provably almost never play it again, unless one of my friends desperately requests it. And finally, the interface of this (digital) game and the overall design is done near-perfectly. å¥½ç©ï¼Œå‰§æƒ…å’Œå…³å¡å¾ˆæ–°å¥‡ï¼Œåˆšå¼€å§‹ç©çš„æ—¶å€™ä¸ç”¨å°å¿ƒç¿¼ç¿¼ï¼Œé™¤éçœ‹æ”»ç•¥èµ°æ­£ç¡®è·¯çº¿ï¼Œè¦ä¸ç„¶éƒ½å¤§å·®ä¸å·® | What I enjoyed:
At first I started this game trying to go in blind. I greatly enjoyed playing the various cards and discovering various interactions and hidden away tidbits in each area and loved being rewarded when I completed small side jobs in each chapter with a new card that gave me new strategies. Plenty of parts of the game have various conclusions & ways to complete tasks that make it fun. Bribe, boast, threaten, discourage or simply defeat enemies during combat, lots of fun routes to play. Sometimes there are even story related resolutions to a conflict via certain items. Some events end differently depending on the items you have on hand or number of pursuers, an early example is the prison break having a satisfyingly obvious difference between having pursuers VS no pursuers. You can even be rewarded depending on how well you perform certain story events. The game has certain consequences along the story as well if you rack up a body count. The game is designed to be played multiple times through each avenue to reach the finish line, and certain knowledge previously obtained helps make future runs easier (figuratively & literally, as prison break has multiple entrances and one can literally be recalled in game and is given as a card item).

What I hated:
There is no skip dialogue or cut-scene button, and for a game that is LITERALLY about replay-ability this is fairly unacceptable. And considering a release date of 2022 that issue isn't likely to be resolved. To top it all off, if you BEAT the game, your save becomes disabled for some insane reason and it simply says congratz thanks for playing (so bear that in mind for true ending pursuit, or lookup how to copy over your save and finish it on a secondary file). Some routes have only a single conclusion to reach, and if you lack the cards to get there or don't understand you might replay a chapter over and over again being stuck and walking in circles not understanding the objective. While you do unlock new cards, they are only for THAT RUN, meaning even tho the games story literally circles back until you reach the "true ending" you lose those new abilities. I personally found this disappointing as getting new tricks only to lose them feels bad.

What I recommend:
If you purchase this game, understand that unless you follow the guide on the forum you WILL fail a few missions or intentionally restart them. And you will have to sit through some dialogue you've already heard until you can get back to the fun. There is lots of fun finding where cards can be used, conventionally and unconventionally (elephant sneeze) and it honestly feels very well thought out in some area's and not so much in others. Near the end you WILL find some "not so obvious" clauses that, so far as i've seen, have only one proper resolution. There is only one walkthrough for this game that I have found and its not all encompassing but DOES get you to the finale, so even if you get frustrated with walking circles you will have a cheat sheet, don't hesitate to use it.

The game is fun, but unless the developer finally decides to fix the lack of dialogue & cut-scene skip for something you will see multiple times, its definitely not for everyone. I would very much recommend the game, but definitely understand "what" you are getting does have a few missing key features and poor design choices in general & later chapters (some are my opinion, some are factual "why is this feature missing"). | å¥½ç©ï¼Œé£æ ¼ç±»ä¼¼è·‘å›¢æ¡Œæ¸¸ï¼Œé€šè¿‡æ¢ç´¢ä¸åŒåœ°ç‚¹å’Œå®ƒä»¬äº§ç”Ÿäº¤äº’ã€‚ç¼ºç‚¹æ˜¯å›æ¡£åŠŸèƒ½åœ¨ç»“å±€å‡ºç°åå°±ä¸èƒ½ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´æœ‰æ—¶å‰§æƒ…çªç„¶ç»“æŸï¼Œäº§ç”Ÿå¤§é‡é‡å¤å·¥ä½œã€‚ | I really like this game for his gimmicks. ĞŸĞ¾Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ±ÑƒÑ ĞµÑ‰Ğµ Ğ½ĞµÑĞºĞ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞºĞ¾ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ· Ğ¸ ĞµÑĞ»Ğ¸ Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞµĞ³Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ÑĞµÑ‚ÑÑ, Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ·Ñ‹Ğ² ĞµÑ‰Ğµ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ½Ñ. | This game was great, but instead of fighting other pirates you now fight:
- Bugs, bugs and more bugs and every update even more bugs created / brought back
- Cheaters, a lot of them (rare lets you do all the work videoreporting them and still do barely anything)
- Desync, hitreg / actionreg, rubber-banding, disconnects, stutter, overall lag, miserable latency, underdeveloped MS Server. 
All of this is getting worse and worse with every update, despite the devs promises for years now.

From a devs perspective: They dug their own graves when they didn't see what a great debug opportunity Arena could have been and instead did everything backwards. 
A minimal game mode with no active events or pve code would be a great debugging platform for underlying problems. This would have also given the possibility of testing updates with more or less a 15-29 mins timeframe for: max lost time for players, time to next possible update without interrupting games and reverting back at any time in case of failure.

But what do I know, I'm just a programmer who likes to game.

 | The game itself is fantasticâ€”the ship and wind mechanics, PvP battles, and especially the stunning wave animations make for an incredible experience. But in its current state, I cannot recommend it. The game is plagued with exploits and, worst of allâ€”cheaters.

[h2]But hey, you can just report them, right? Sure! You just need to follow these SIMPLE steps:[/h2]

[list]
[*]Pre-record all your gameplay or use an instant replay feature (Don't have a high-end PC? Too bad!)
[*]Manually gather evidence and put together a solid report.
[*]Submit the report through a long, outdated browser-based process with strict criteria (such as capturing the cheater's nametagâ€”which is much harder than it sounds).
[*]Deal with ridiculous limitationsâ€”only five evidence files per report, each under 50MB. If your files are too big, youâ€™ll need to upload them elsewhere.
[/list]

Easy peasy, right? And even if you do all that and receive confirmation that the cheater was banned, it's just a minor inconvenience for them. Why? Because of ban evasion. Without going into too much detail, they can simply create a new account in under five minutesâ€”without even repurchasing the game.

[h2]But I still like the game. Can I give feedback, suggest solutions, or discuss the cheater problem with the community?[/h2]

Whoa, whoa! Easy there, champ. Turns out, thatâ€™s not allowed either. Apparently, players are only supposed to report cheaters and trust that the devs are â€œworking on it.â€ But hey, give them timeâ€”itâ€™s not like this game has been out for over five years, right? ğŸ˜ƒ

Hereâ€™s part of a response from a staff member on the official Sea of Thieves forums:

"[...] Dropping anchor here as while we know this comes from a good place and of wanting to make the game better, and we do as well, the forums is not the space to discuss solutions when it comes to these things. This is because only the internal team know of what is and isn't possible and it is not something that is easily solved or has a quick solution. [...]"

[h2]To summarize:[/h2]

Reporting a single cheater takes far too much time. And if we consider the time a player loses at the hands of a cheater, letâ€™s not forget:

[list]
[*]You could lose a boat full of treasure (representing two or more hours of gameplay).
[*]You could lose an Hourglass streak that took several hours to build.
[*]And now, on top of that, youâ€™re expected to waste more of your time filing a detailed reportâ€”a job that shouldnâ€™t be yours in the first place.
[/list]

[h2]To be fair...[/h2]

They do fix exploitsâ€”eventually.
But if you donâ€™t mind a game infested with cheaters, go aheadâ€”itâ€™s a great game.
