No. They scrapped the marriage system after claiming they would do it during early access for a lame roommate system.  If i didn't feel like i got burned for buying it during early access i'd probably recommend it to someone who doesn't care about romance | I recommend this game, but with a few caveats. I even recommend it at full price because I want more game similar to this... but with other significant changes.

Firstly, know that this is a farming sim game with wuxia vibes. If you had hoped for interesting martial arts, high stakes drama, conflicting ideologies, relations or conflicts between multiple sects, and wise masters to learn from then you won't find them here. This game is about farming, fishing, raising bees and silkworms, and building a small village (your sect). In doing that your character learns something about cultivation, but the MAIN thing is farming. Honestly, I don't even know what the Guiyun sect values other than they seem to be 'good guys'.

Secondly, know that the game has a tremendous amount of grind. Truly monumental amounts. Even with the Jade Pendant upgraded to level 11 (maybe the max upgrade to level 12 helps...?) it is a ton. By the second spring I had reached my cultivation limit, had a fully upgraded house, had completed every side quest, and had an almost unlimited amount of money. Then I realized that there was a sect journal, and I had neglected one person and so the main story line had been delayed. None of the things I did counted; once you reach the point where you need to breakthrough you simply stop learning. None of the experience you gained applies to the next level, meaning you have to grind it all out again. While this mimics a sort of real life plateau that people come to in periods of training or development, it isn't fun in a game. It took a long time to get to a point where I could breakthrough because countless quests require you to 'wait one day'. It completely breaks the immersion when you end up sleeping for 23 hours, getting a letter, and sleeping for 23 hours.

Don't get me wrong, I have had fun in the first 60 hours of gameplay. I like the farming and the fishing and the people and the dungeons. Yet at this point everything feels very artificial. The gaps between breakthroughs are HUGE, the tutors you can hire never seem to get better, and now I have to do another kind of farming in the Blessed Land... 

I hate the Blessed Land crops. They really feel like an extremely inorganic way of padding the length of the game. You constantly need to dig up crops in order to plant new ones of different types, you have to move these flags around, you have to wait until the next day for any seeds to contribute energy... why? It's all so arbitrary and tedious. I'm already an excellent farmer. I'm already an excellent combatant. I look cool and my house is fully upgraded and I have more money than I can spend. Yet I have to spend AGES growing these crops...

In order to grow them efficiently I need more materials, which means going into dungeons, and that is a bore. I have only made it to the Blazing Sands dungeon and, from the looks of it, I have 4 or 5 more to look forward to. Visually they all have a cool look even if most of them are palette swapped versions of each other. The enemies have been different in each locale; despite having lizards everywhere some will bite and others shoot bullets and some have lasers. so there is diversity in how they attack you. Yet you have one main attack, a sort of sword beam, and it is extremely boring. You also do have spells, but I've never felt the need to use any other than the starting spell. It attacks a huge area, pierces enemies, and usually one shots opponents even if they share the same element. There are other elements for spells, but I have never once needed an advantage that way. 

So lets say you need Mirror Sand for a pot to grow your Blessed Land fruit faster... well, you can do a run in the Blazing Desert and, with certain blessings and luck, you might come away with enough Mirror Sand to make one pot... about ten units. Now you have to do that 8 more times. Then you have to do it for everything else that costs Mirror Sand, like houses and other upgrades. It is EXTREMELY tedious. 

You can eventually gain movement speed buffs from food and alchemy (you unlock food first, and from what I can tell, food is ALWAYS better for some reason). Once you do, you realize just how SLOW this main character is. Again, this isn't a wuxia game. You cannot train lightness of body, jump higher, or run faster (your character actually never gets better at ANYTHING they do. I guess you can upgrade stats like divinity and stance but throughout the whole game I have never noticed them making a difference in anything. Fishing is still slow. You never attack faster. Your tools and spells and things get better but YOU don't). The only way to gain a movement boost is via consumables most of which run out incredibly quickly. This contributes to just how frustrating the grind can be, at least until you can use blessings to make huge quantities of cabbage soup, then you just need to ensure you have tons of those ingredients. 

Finally, know that there are no deadlines or tension of any kind. Everything can wait. There are no emergencies, time limits, or stakes at all (...in quests that matter. There are some job board quests that have time limits and quick completion rewards but the quests themselves can be ignored and are eventually very trivial). This is fine for many people, but for me it just renders the whole activity pointless and artificial feeling after a while. There is no skill involved. The only obstacle between you and your goals is time... and I am finally reaching a point where I feel like my time is better spent elsewhere.

I do love the characters... I sort of want to know what happened to the sect... but everything is revealed so extremely slowly that it might as well not matter at all. With every story quest I complete someone asks me to do another chore or recruit another person but nothing really develops. At first it felt like I was making progress fixing the sect, but now I'm growing weird magic crops for no reason because my crops aren't magic enough...? I have enjoyed the time I've spent with Immortal Life, and I am a huge fan of wuxia, but this just feels like a job at this point. I leave crops in the field unharvested. I don't check the beehives anymore. I truly don't need to do any of it and don't want to do any of it either. 

I still recommend the game: it is fun for quite a long time, at least 40 hours playing and a full year of the game. Once you start to master the system, or if you are a power gamer, or if you seek external motivation, or if you are motivated by a developing story then maybe this isn't for you. If you do play it, I cannot recommend enough using the sect journal to be continuously completing the main story so you don't end up wasting your time.

å·®è¯„ï¼Œä¸å–œæ¬¢ |         -Very enjoyable game that mixes farming with the cultivation from Chinese wuxia. In a world full of mostly stardew valley clones this stands out with a game-play loop that very different so for anyone seeking a different experience than what we are used to this is a game for you. The game initially is much more focused on farming, however as you continue to cultivate you will be able to do this faster from running around swinging two blades to harvest your entire field in seconds to having large clouds that can water 50 or so plots very rapidly and eventually the whole farming aspect becomes automated other then planting and harvesting. 

        -This is where you enter the 2nd phase of the game where the focus is no longer on farming but cultivating and completing the sect journal to rebuild the Guiyun sect. Finally phase 3 is once again a focus on farming extra special plants with the use of mystic tools. All the characters are relatively interesting and overall storyline was enough to keep me invested which is definetly a step up compared to many games in this genre. 

        -The combat is simple and is essentially a twin stick shooter game where you running launching flying blades and use spell-like abilities to do things such as conjuring tornadoes, breathing fire or throwing boulders at enemies. 

        -Also you don't need to sleep because you are a cultivator, you can to restore health, mana and stamina but it is not necessary so no rushing back to your bed every 10 minutes. 

        -The cooking mini-game caught me off guard and is extremely enjoyable

        -Game play really well on controller as well HOWEVER, you can't rebind the keys and b is accept while a is cancel which broke my mind the first few times I played it, you get used to it but it's definitely annoying the first time around.

        -My one real gripe with the game is that the sect journal has no tutorial so many players miss it, I see it all the time in the discussion section of steam. To anyone picking this game up for the first time make sure you pay attention to the sect journal you can access it by pressing escape, quests and then switching the tab to sect journal, it will tell you how to unlock the new quests and when you will unlock additional features like different dungeons, new sect members etc. If you don't do this you can find yourself locked out of content for ages because some of them have esoteric unlock conditions like be in this one spot between  10 and 12pm or check in on someone 7 times over 7 different days etc. | Very addicting to play. Living my cultivation dreams yesssss. Hope at the end there will be an option for Dao Companionship. Hoping for more cn games like this.

Quiplash 3: Aesthetically one of the more unique ones of the Jackbox series, featuring claymation-style elements. Quiplash is Quiplash, you fill in the blanks of sentences and make a ha-ha. The only caveat I have with this version is the music - in the soundtrack it's fine, but during gameplay, it's intimidating even... but it's easily brushed off.

The Devils and the Details: Hhhhhhhh - mixed feelings. It's a group game where some tasks are independent, some require teamwork. You fill a bar with the tasks you do and move to the next day. Here, it really depends on the group of people you are playing with - playing with people other than those that you have vocal contact with is borderline impossible, just because of the teamwork-required tasks. Even then, this is something I occasionally play with a group of people and get joy out of it. Occasionally = far less than the other games, but still played.

Champ'd Up: To this day, still probably the best drawing game in Jackbox Packs. You draw characters based on a prompt, and then get a rival whose appearance you see, but don't know the prompt. Then they fight each other. It's so simple in concept, but really fun. Also, bonus points to the music - Andy Poland went hard and I appreciate it, really digging the electronic music mixed with march band drums. Kinda reminds me of Death Grips' earlier works through that.

Talking Points: Vocal improvisation, the game - speaking is mandatory in this game, and so, should be played with those with vocal contact. You get a topic for a slideshow, but don't know the pictures that a different player chooses for you. This game usually gets extremely restless and out-of-bounds, which can be really fun at times. Freeplay-mode for this is an odd choice.

Blather 'Round: This game is one of my go-to games when introducing Jackbox to other players (others being Tee K.O. and Guesspionage). You get a thing that you have to explain about with using cryptic words, and give "praise/discipline" to player-given answers (in other words, you can agree, or don't agree with a word to lead others onward). Fun and engaging, best with a big player group. This game should've gotten the Freeplay-mode, but I guess such wasn't picked up for the potential difficulty of giving custom words the prompts that the game gives you?

Genres: Adventure, Indie, RPG, Strategy, Early Access
Reviews: A very basic and, after all, dull deckbuilder with standard mechanics and off-the-shelf optics. In early access for 5 years now, during which nothing has happened. Also overpriced, in my opinion. Better keep away.

Si je pouvais jouer Ã  ce jeu pour la premiÃ¨re fois encore une fois je le ferais volontier.

I know most people compare it to stardew valley, and while i do not think it right to judge games only by comparing them, i'll still say that i like roots of pacha way better. The pre-historic setting itches that part of my brain that loves historical settings. As an agriculture major, i hugely appreciate the fact that there is undomesticated and domesticated versions of every crop, and i think it would be really cool if the domesticated plants gave larger crop, too; as larger harvests were one of the major goals in the domestication process, alongside disease resistance and all, of course. The ideas and recipes make it so that you really want to grow every crop, instead of just mass-producing the most valuable one. It is also lgbtq+ and polygamy friendly, which, while i dont specifically care for, am sure a lot of folk appreciate. It also feels more wholesome, in a way; not that i dont love stardew valley, dont get me wrong; but even if you chose the community center route, stardew is still a largely money-driven game. Instead of fixing up a community center that npc's sometimes go to and you mostly forget about after maybe the second year; in roots of pacha it feels like you really are helping the community. Overall; great concept, nice soundtrack, your kids actually grow up and become human beings, you can trap or raise animals for meat, there is a genetics system for animals, great game all around. And also you can have a pet wolf. Come on now. Dont you want a pet wolf. | A fantastic iteration of the farming sim genre. The formula is familiar but the setting, storyline, and slightly altered mechanics make it stand out and not feel like a copy paste of other games. No combat so much more laidback than other games. Only complaint would be that the animal taming system can be a bit grindy and tedious if you want rare variations of animals. I had pretty much finished the game by the time I got an animal with maxed out stats. Some of the end game content does make getting variations easier, but breeding for stats still takes a long time for what feels like little reward. 
Other than that, it's probably my favorite farming sim that I've played and holds very well against the genre standard of Stardew Valley. | I do love a farming simulator, but this adds so much to the cozy aesthetic. The creativity in this game is unmatched and i have never seen so many fantasy, and historical elements in a game like this. I really do hope it gets the love it deserves | Ã“timo jogo!  | La verdad es que este juego lo llevo jugando desde que salio, sin embargo lo jugaba pirateado en vieja pc, en cuanto mejore con respecto a pc lo primero que compre fue este juego y no eh parado de jugarlo. | I'd give it a 7/10

I had a lot of fun playing this game on my steamdeck while traveling but I will 100% say this game feels kind of unfinished and poorly balanced. A lot of my enjoyment was derived from trying to figure out how to win on the harder difficulties with each character in spite of the poor balancing. 

It's definitely a neat concept that I havent seen done before and I enjoyed discovering neat combinations of tiles on the map like Village + Vampire Manor = Vampire Town. But I wish there was more of that. There should be dozens and dozens of combinations and interactions, but there's really not. It feels like there's content waiting to be implemented but it just never came. 

It's got some soft "gambling" elements in that you can end runs early to cash in your treasure or you can always go for another loop or attempt a boss in an all-or-nothing kind of way. It's fun but frustrating in a not so great way. | Fantastic game and gorgeous visuals, normally not a fan of grindy games, but this feels like you make genuine progress every time you play

Tho one thing linux users should know, make sure compatibility layer uses the latest version of proton!

Genres: Casual, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Early Access
Reviews:
Most Early Access Games I'm pretty chill about, I play what's there and then forget about it for months. I think this is the first game in a LONG time that I am sitting here screaming, crying, throwing up that it is not fully out yet.
That is to say: I think I'm genuinely quite bad at several of the vital components of this game and I'm STILL having a fantastic time. Everything comes together in a really fascinating way I don't think I've seen in many games before. Friendship is VITAL to story progression and battling capabilities, farming is closely tied to your ability to upgrade your blob's health and stamina, several items can ONLY be found in blob worlds... It's genuinely engaging to be forced to interact with every aspect of the game so naturally! Even the battle level-up system is unique! I'm not just spamming my strongest attack every battle, because if I do so, my blobs will actually get WEAKER since I'm only leveling one of three attributes. It's an incredible experience and I look forward to vibrating with intensity while patiently waiting for more updates to come :) | I would recommend Ova Magica to anyone who enjoys the farming/life sim style games. Claudia the dev has done a phenomenal job of listening to feedback both from steam and discord.

Pros 
- Combat is both easy to learn and intricate enough to be enjoyable
- Farming is worth it, as you need many of the crops to upgrade Blobs
- The NPCs all have unique personalities, and they are carefully created
- The blob worlds are procedural generated, so each visit yields different rewards

Cons
- The leveling system of the blobs' stats took me a while to catch on (this seems to have been addressed in v0.8 with the blob training

The game is still in early access, so the game is still improving. Each update has given hours of new gameplay so I am excited to see what 2025 brings for the game! | This is such a cute game! I can't wait for it to fully release. It reminds me of Pokemon and Harvest moon. |  It's a mix of all the best parts of farm and creature collection games. It's very incomplete at the moment but I'm already falling in love with it's potential. | This game has it all tons of fun and I love the new content they are adding even though the game is still in early access there is so much fun to be had. Highly recommend this game it has blobs you can catch, fishing,farming and crafting.

Damn I can't believe I finally finished this. Officially my 2nd most played game on Steam o.o

Going into this I knew it was a mobile port, so I wasn't expecting *much*, maybe the other reviewers didn't know that, but either way I think "mostly negative" is a tad bit harsh.

Yeah the game is very very basic, it lacks pretty much all the basic things you'd expect from a nonogram:

- Doesn't cross off completed numbers/hints. You don't even get the option to do it yourself.
- No accessibility settings at all, even basic stuff like background colour change/font size etc.
- Like stated above, the font size is TINY on bigger nonograms, for basically no reason as there is 100% space for them to be larger. I often confused 8 with 6 as well as 3 and 5 ALL the time and it of course isn't a good thing to get the numbers wrong. 
- In my opinion the "what line you have hovered over" indicator needs to be waaay darker. I struggled to see which line I was on often.
- Puzzle sizes are random (apart from maybe the first few), so sometimes you get thrown a bunch of easy, and then a lot of hards, no matter where you are in progress. If that's your thing then cool, but sometimes you just wanna do one or the other. You can't skip ahead on levels so you can't just go pick another level either.
- It's very easy to mess up and click a square by accident, so you either clear it or turn it into an x/filled. Literally every other nonogram game I've played stops you being able to paint over X's.
- A lot of wording is clearly from the mobile game which they haven't bothered changing for the PC version, like "tap" instead of click.
- Lack of title/description for finished pictures. Sometimes I still had no idea what they were even when they were completed/coloured in. 

There's honestly probably a bunch more things I've forgotten. But all I'm really saying is the game is very very basic, but I clearly enjoyed it hence the 130 hours playtime, so rating badly would just be stupid of me. That doesn't mean I can't advise you against playing, because imo there are plenty of better nonogram games on Steam (I just happened to have already played most of them already). 

 | I'm still playing for some inexplicable reason, but there are much better picross/nonogram games out there.

If you're stuck on a puzzle, there is no way to progress other than to just keep trying or pay more money. This model is common in mobile games but unexpected and frustrating in Steam games. | [u]Recommendation[/u]: Good value for a while, but eventually I stopped enjoying it when the puzzles could no longer be solved with logic alone.

[u]Review[/u]: You are exploring the world's desserts, sampling sweets all over the world as you travel across abstracted, goofy versions of several continents. Completing each puzzle reveals a picture of some dessert or dessert-related item: a bonbon, an ice cream cone, a gumball machine, and so forth. As with any freemium game, you can play the entire game for free from beginning to end, or you can buy coins (which are used to travel) or hints for real money. The puzzles quickly get difficult enough that using a hint will be really tempting, but you can use the coins that accumulate for free over time as well. I tried to complete one puzzle a day, and at that rate I never had to pay money, and my ability to use logic to determine which spaces have to be part of the picture and which spaces cannot be part of the picture - the whole point of nonogram puzzles - was sufficient to complete every puzzle...up until a point.

Unfortunately for me, I am simultaneously working my way through two other nonogram puzzle games, and I have played several others in the past. This game suffers in the comparison. There are a bunch of little things done in other nonogram games that in this Picross Bonbon game are either inferior or flat-out missing. Together these little things eventually added up to my realization that I was continuing to play not because I was enjoying the game but because I was reluctant to give up on something I'd started. That coincided with a big step up in difficulty of the puzzles the game was presenting.

But I *did* enjoy this game to begin with; the puzzles on the first continent represent a nice progression in difficulty, without being so complex that the UI issues and missing features scream in your face. I think it's pretty good value at first, and then that diminishes the further you get in the game. 

[u]Critique[/u]: First of all, I should point out that this game has a user interface seemingly modeled after mobile games. I don't know if it is a port of a mobile game or a game that was simultaneously released across different platforms, but there's a bunch of mobile game features present here. This isn't a huge issue for me, but I know it is a sticking point for some. For example, there's the three-star rating system for each puzzle: complete a puzzle and you are awarded one, two, or three stars. There's also a goofy menu system of nested screens, so if you want to quit the game, you have to bring up the menu, select the map icon, return to the map, then click the "return/go back" arrow, return to the title screen, then click the "X" icon to quit the game...rather than the usual game convention of bringing up the ESC menu and selecting "Quit." Like I said, it's a lot of little things like this that ultimately make the game irritating to play.

But I could overlook those if the gameplay interface was better. For better or worse (I say worse), the puzzle gameplay in Picross Bonbon is the closest to what I imagine playing a nonogram in a book or newspaper would be like: the interface doesn't tell you whether you've put the marks in the correct place, nor does it tell you whether you've completed a row or column correctly. It will tell you that the conditions of the row or column have been met: you have put in 8 - 2 - 5 - 1 in that column...but you could have put them in randomly, and they could be completely incorrect.

However, the biggest, most egregious foul in the nonogram gameplay to my mind is that you will eventually reach puzzles where you have to GUESS (or use a hint). One should absolutely never, EVER have to guess when solving a logic puzzle. When you work on solving a logic puzzle, you need to KNOW that if you are guessing in that logic puzzle, you're missing something. But in this game, you WILL get to the point where you have to make a blind choice between two or three possible locations for a mark, and then you have to play through a bunch more of the puzzle before you discover whether you guessed correctly. Of course, you can consider that your guess might be a bit more "educated" if you consider the picture that is being formed and choose something that fits better with the image. Your mileage may vary, but this is just terrible to me.

I suspect that the game designers want to present you with situations where you can't know what the right choice is, or reason out the correct choice, so that you will spend currency on hints that will reveal the truth to you without ever showing you WHY you mark one space and not another. That idea - that you would make a logic puzzle that cannot be solved by logic - is so filthy to me I had a hard time getting my fingers to type it through my disgust.

I couldn't believe it at first, but then the situation where I had to guess started recurring more and more often. It's not a fluke. It's a very broken feature of the game. I hate giving up on a game without finishing it, but here I could not finish it without guessing or using "hints" to solve it for me. So I'm going to have to give up on this one. | ç”»é¢å¾ˆå¯çˆ±ï¼Œåœ°å›¾ä¸ŠQå¼¹çš„æœå†»è¶…èŒï¼Œä½œä¸ºæ•°å›¾ç±»æ¸¸æˆç®—æ¯”è¾ƒå¤æ‚çš„ï¼Œé”™è¯¯æ—¶æ²¡æœ‰æç¤ºã€‚
ä¸çŸ¥ä¸ºä½•ï¼Œæ˜æ˜å·²ç»è·å–äº†å…¶å®ƒæ‰€æœ‰æˆå°±ï¼Œæœ€åä¸€ä¸ªâ€œè·å–å…¨éƒ¨å¥–æ¯â€çš„æˆå°±æ— è®ºå¦‚ä½•éƒ½ç‚¹ä¸äº®ï¼Œå¯èƒ½æ˜¯ä¸ªBUGï¼Œæˆå°±æ§æ…å…¥â€¦â€¦ | This is why one should always read the reviews before buying. I saw that this was a picross/nonogram game and I purchased it immediately without reading the reviews. Big Mistake. Turns out, this is the worst nonogram game I've ever played on steam, and I have many of them in my collection.

In this game, you can't mark a specific number as done, hence making you count each square again if you're playing the bigger puzzles. 

You have to be soooo careful while filling the squares because you can easily unmark them or mark another square. 

Dragging a line with lift click or right click will immediately replace a square with different input that you've already filled earlier, like for example, you can't just drag your mouse to mark the rest of the row as X because it will overwrite the squares on the column on its path that you've already marked before! This to me is the deal-breaker as its the most stupid UX design for a nonogram game.

The learning curve is also crazy, you start off with medium and hard puzzles immediately, lolz. I'm ok with that as I'm a seasoned nonogram player but beginners will find this difficult.

Conclusion: I never knew it was possible to rage quit a nonogram game until I played this one.

Not a bad game per session, and I was actually having a lot of fun. Until I went to multiplayer.

The movement there is just broken to the point of being unplayable.
Everyone makes the orders on their turn, then the movement and attacks happen in a seemingly random order.
This means that if you're the last in turn order you can get your big unit move blocked by a scout. 
You'll get shot first before getting to do anything. 
You'll get flanked because you've not moved yet, so the enemy has perfect knowledge.
You'll have your disembarks move blocked - the charge card you paid for? Wasted. Pick a different cell next turn? Then can just move to it.

It's not just bad, it's infuriatingly unfair if you're not player 1. | Unlike some other games, you do not need to spend a whole days working at a map; sometimes a half hour is enough, leaving you time to play another round or just to avoid the necessity of trying to cram two hours of sleep before the morning alarm clock. There are many modes to try; I particularly like the Hegemony battles - not because I always win but because I sometimes don't although I wish there were a forum for each of the various civilisations (factions) so that I could see if there are other players that consistently favour one or some civs over others rather than just wondering if folks are merely jumping onto the bandwagon of the one leading faction.. The developers are good at staying on top of the little issues. | Very nice game, but unfortunately very badly balanced... to bad!

Will give it a thumps up anyways, because besides the balance its pretty neat. | Low online in MP but otherwise a great game. I just wish it got updated more often | the more I play it, the more I like it. gives a pretty great 4x experience in a reasonable time session.

Reviews: No Reviews

ì´ ê²Œì„ ìì˜í•œ ë²„ê·¸ (ë•Ÿëª©ì—ì„œ ì•ˆ ë‚˜ì™€ì§„ë‹¤ë˜ê°€, ì›ìˆ­ì´ë“¤ì´ ê°‘ìê¸° ì‚¬ë¼ì ¸ì„œ ë©€ë¦¬ ë¿… ìƒê¸´ë‹¤ë˜ê°€)ê°€ ì€ê·¼íˆ ë§ì€ë° ì›ìˆ­ì´ í›ˆë ¨ì‹œì¼œì„œ ì¼í•˜ê²Œ ë§Œë“ ë‹¤ëŠ” ì•„ì´ë””ì–´ë„ ì¢‹ì•˜ê³  ì¸ë””ê²Œì„ íŠ¹ìœ ì˜ ì†Œì†Œí•œ ì¬ë¯¸ê°€ ìˆì–´ ì¶”ì²œí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. íŒŒë°, í¬ë˜í”„íŒ… ì¬ë¯¸ë„ ìˆêµ¬ìš”. ë‹¤ë§Œ ë„ê³¼ ë”°ì‹œëŠ” ë¶„ë“¤ ë©€í‹°í•˜ë©´ ê²ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸ëŠ” ì•ˆ ë˜ê³  í˜¸ìŠ¤íŠ¸ë§Œ ë”°ì§€ëŠ” ë¶€ë¶„ì´ ìˆìœ¼ë‹ˆ ë°©ì¥ì„ ë°”ê¿”ê°€ë©° ë…¸ê°€ë‹¤ë¥¼ ì¢€ í•´ì•¼ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤ ã…  | This would be a great survival game with a lot of great elements, but unfortunately some poor design choices and bugs prevent the player to get immersed.

At first the fact that every action can be done with only one key, (space) looks like a great approach, but given that -everything- is perfomed by that, very often unvanted actions occur/trigger, which is very annoying.
You should forget about this and use a proper key assignment layout like other decent games.

Also the item handling, splitting, etc. is very different from the already widely established scheme based on common sense.
On its own it would not be an issue. If it would work fine. But it is messy and don't have much logic.

In the mazes, the camera movement is quite unfortunate as the snapping or stationary camera is not a good idea when all of the other parts of the game use a camera fixed on the player.
As the camera stops on the border of rooms and only snaps to the next room when the player enters, it cannot be seen exactly what is on the other side of the door, even when open. So a situation when a player enters another room in the face of an enemy without seeing it, can happen and get attacked.
Which is silly.

Quite often we had desyncs and players dropped, which is also very annoying.
The last drop was when in a maze all of our progress got lost due to a disconnection/desync error.

Due to these and if a game produces this many bugs and is this unstable, then at least a usual rotating autosave feature would be nice, so users would have a way to restore the lost content and time.

I guess no devs will read this or will not give a damn anyway, but if you want to improve your game, then here you go.

Have seen beta games in better shape than this. | This game got old really, really fast.  The monkeys were kind of annoying more than helpful, and I get the impression the game was just kind of dumped mid-development.  Gonna be a nah from me. | I really wanted to like this game but i just can't. I tried to finish it twice but i gave up.
The visuals are great, i really like the pixel art and i got it really cheap.
But it all falls apart with the gameplay, the monkey system is okayish when you have a few monkeys around.
-The game has only four directions of combat, but everything can attack you from a diagonal
-The ui is terrible, whith constant shuffleing of items and materials with very non-intuitive controls
-one button to interact with everything makes the game frustrating after a while (random weapon swaping with monkeys during gathering).
-if there are more items on one tile. welll... though luck, you need to pick it all up (also move the monkey standing there)
-after about an hour or two it becoms a total grind for resources, which involves only going from island A to island B click a bunch of items and return.
-building a base is very bare bones and i had no satisfaction in doing so. (god forbid you want a wooden floor everywhere)
-every aspect of the game feels like its strapped on only to get the game to be longer and not interesting or fun. | This game has an issue with saving whenever I tried to load one of my saves it sets me back to when I first saved (when you generate a world)

Honestly, at the price it's at, there's not much to lose if you're looking for an interesting challenge. The concept is great and so is the design, but it lacks tutorial and is overall pretty finicky. Majority of the time spent playing is wasted on running away from skeletons or constantly redirecting the people to actually go through with the action you give them. At some point, it gets so tiring and stressful to constantly have to set new paths just so that the little guys can avoid a tiny obstacle. Especially when it comes to hunting, it's just so impossible for the code to actually follow through without constantly losing track of the deer. I get that's the point, but with skeletons being so overpowered and having the ability to walk through fences, it leaves little to no room for actual progression if there is a constant need for intervention with every task. | This game feels almost...Unfinished. I understand the model the company is going for with the "one game released every two weeks", but it leads to not the best experience when playing the games.

Pyramida has no tutorial at all, and no way to figure out the commands of the game; there's nothing in it explaining how to start playing, and I had to come back to the discussion board to see if anyone else had the same problem (the answer is yes lol). There's also no pause button, a stylistic choice per the developer - however, the dev said you can just quit the game whenever you want to pause. If you can quit the game to pause, what difference does it make to not have a pause button?

The game was stressful but not in a "oh, this is challenging!" way. It was stressful in a way that killed any wish I had to keep playing. | It's a cute game, simplistic art style and so forth. However, the game can glitch at times and it lacks a tutorial - it's unclear on how you're supposed to play. Once you understand how, it's quite easy to pick up though. Regardless of this, can't fault the price of it. | Fun game, little stressful during the night. Once you figure out the food, it is just waitingfor finish.
Not long, completed in 3rd run after 4 hours, some achivement still left, maybe later (which means "probably not ever doing") | was positively surprised how enthralling the game was. it's very small and simple, but I enjoyed it quite a lot.

[b]Iâ€™ve beaten the game all the way up to floor 10, and feel satisfied with this accomplishment up to now. Luck be a Landlord is casual fun, and for a casual price I think thatâ€™s pretty awesome. But itâ€™s missing the X factor that makes me think itâ€™s really special.[/b]

This will probably be short since the game itself is very condensed. The premise isâ€¦ completely nonsensical, but whatever. It took me until my 5th run or so before I even bothered to read the text. Itâ€™s irrelevant.

The gameplay is simply two loops, one very miniature, and another bite-sized. You spin the slot machine, earn some amount of money, and you choose to add a symbol to it (or not). After a certain number of spins, you have to pay rent, get an [b]item[/b] (different from a symbol), and then the next rent payment is even higher.

Once you reach a high enough â€œfloorâ€, you begin receiving essences after some of the rent payments, too. These are, at the risk of being overly simple, like temporary forms of the items, with usually greater (but time-limited) payoffs.

This is everything you do in the game.

The symbols themselves are not the most pleasing things to look at, but the thematic synergies are cute. Dwarves drink beer. With an item they can also smash ore. Billionaires synergize with wine and cheese. Divers collect aquatic type items and give permanently higher payouts after collecting them. Itâ€™s cutesy like this.

It also does a very good job at showing you with a little animation and sound effect [i]when the effect happens[/i]. I appreciate that as itâ€™s a relatively common complaint of mine in other roguelike/lite games that these games are opaque.

What prevents me from really loving this one is the stark contrast between a run feeling completely blessed by the gods, and a complete car wreck. And the best way to go about beating the game consistently, is the least satisfying way of doing so.

The best way to go about beating the game is just simply to take whatever symbol and item best synergizes with what you have going on in your slot machine already. What this means is that playing best often means two things:

[b]1)[/b] You finish with a hodge-podge of different good symbols and items, without a unifying theme and identity.

[b]2)[/b] Thereâ€™s not much looking forward to anything or building toward something.

Some runs you [i]will[/i] pick every club, spade, heart, and diamond, and you will be blessed by like 2 jokers to perfectly tie it together. But nothing you did before that moment you received the jokers helped you get them. Sometimes youâ€™ll take every aquatic item there is, and then snag a diver who after a few rolls is already giving you 12 per spin. But again, nothing you did before that moment helped you snag the diver.

More often than not, building toward a specific synergy will result in a loss because you never get the payoff. And why would you take the payoff before you built up the base?

My personal recommendation for the game would be to have a system similar to the boons in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1145360/Hades/]Hades[/url]. In Hades you need certain boons before you can earn others. They donâ€™t [b]increase[/b] your odds at getting the boon, but there is a level of satisfaction to knowing youâ€™re building toward your goal, so to speak. And I think Luck Be a Landlord would benefit from this, even if it meant the gameâ€™s difficulty had to be increased in conjunction.

Itâ€™s not about difficulty as much as it is about satisfaction.

The other limiters are things like a collection log, a list of run modifiers to toggle, among other things. There [u]is[/u] a Steam Workshop, which I will readily admit Iâ€™ve yet to explore, but I will later. And maybe these things can be found there. In all likelihood they do exist there. And without developer effort, the workshop wouldnâ€™t be there, and easy to use, so despite the fact the developer didnâ€™t make the mods, they provided the framework. That deserves credit.

Ultimately though, Luck be a Landlord is limited by its core build philosophy. Itâ€™s a fine game, and has a good feel of low stakes. The price point is low, and the gameplay is simple and cute. But itâ€™s not one Iâ€™ll really remember or recommend above many other games, although the very affordable price on sales is noteworthy!

I've loved this game for years, however i cannot recommend it, considering the state of the studio and how they manage the game and their team. They prioritize quantity over quality, money over anything else, trying to pay as little as possible to their employees and not crediting free work put into the game. 
i recommend to watch this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ouSWPM4jfUY

Pixel Sprout games; Artists, programmers, writers, translators and everyone else deserves to be paid properly. they are the only reason this game is what it is. They deserve better and you should be fucking ashamed | I cannot recommend this game, at all. 

I loved this game, I bought it for friends (19 people, I have bought this game for 19 people). It was SDV but fantasy and I loved it, but it really isn't possible for me to recommend this game anymore. I've played this since it was Early Access. I have 380 hours in this game, almost all the achievements. 

The team has consistently dropped the ball with various things:
- no credits for any of the creators, artists, coders, etc
- nintendo switch issues
- issues with the discord and questions not being answered
- people not receiving codes
- constant dlc release
- so many bugs, even on PC (I have lost saves at times)
- awful translations for different languages (with unpaid work)

This could've been something new, something better. And it isn't. The community was horribly failed. Do better, please. Hire more community managers or communicate better. It's unacceptable the amount of times people have brought up in the discord not receiving codes or entirely being ignored. The team does NOT communicate with the player base at all. The switch version was released entirely broken. Nintendo told customers to contact Pixel Sprout for refunds and I saw multiple times that the people asking about that and the refunds were ignored. Only now are they trying to backtrack after all the backlash. I get it that it can cause issues, but communication has been HORRIBLE. At most, they announce "we know it's broken, and we don't know when it'll be fixed, oopsie". The radio silence for other players has been disheartening to see. 

The translators at first were volunteers. Then the dev team cut them off and used some stupid AI translation. Then they had people "volunteer" to fix their machine translation. 

Employees were also not paid fairly. People were paid well below minimum wage. Everything is out there, just look into it. There's multiple posts from former employees, google documents, tweets-- all have evidence and proof.

People were banned for bringing up concerns in the discord or for speaking up about various issues. I might get banned myself for posting this review. It's unacceptable behavior. Stop being defensive and own up to mistakes. 

As for the actual game? It's cute, the pixel graphics are nice (some of them are wonky). The story is okay. The immersion is pretty good, but it drops the ball in some other areas, like relationships and marriage. NPCs are unique, there's plenty of different characters for everyone. Furniture is still not able to be turned for the majority of things. The story needs to have a lot of retcon or fixing, I think. So far? It's you grind, you go to a elf city, you talk to a dragon. You go to a demon city, then you either give stuff to a dragon or fight it, and then there's nothing after. It's a very boring story in places and very grindy. The seasonal enemies are fun. DLCs are done right only for the sole fact that they're cosmetic only and don't really do much for gameplay itself.

Look into what you're purchasing first. I'm highly disappointed with the team and the way they have behaved as well as the way they have treated the community. I'm not buying any Pixel Sprout games ever again and I'm telling all of my friends, family, even strangers, to do the same. 

Highly recommend Fields of Mistria, Stardew Valley, various other games in that vein as opposed to Sun Haven. I'm sure there are going to be more fantasy stardew-esque games from better developers and better company. | ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ ã¯é¢ç™½ã„ãŒæ—¥æœ¬èªç¿»è¨³ãŒé…·ã„ã€‚

This game has a lot going for it, but it doesn't stick the landing as well as other deck-building games. The sub-par tutorialization made the gameplay confusing to follow and progression was not satisfying enough for me to continue. | Good or not good, it's everyone's opinion. in any case I find that this game was made with great passion and a lot of originality. it is an artisanal work. I watched the entire credits and it is here that we realize the significant human investment that this requires. thanks to violinist Aleksandra Fikus for the accompaniment.

given the general quality of the game I feel like I stole this game by buying it on sale for the price of a beer. I played for a few hours, the game is not easy but the tutorial is well done. I believe that several parts are useful to familiarize yourself with the techniques of the game. Frankly in its style this game is much superior to many of its peers put forward on the Steam platform.

I absolutely adore this game. Please don't be put off by the "limited" playtime - you very quickly find plenty to do!

I've played on Switch and Steam and both versions ran pretty well, with only some minor lag when Flamey's fully ignited.
The bears' stories are beautifully woven and well worth exploring to the end. Valentina is one of my favourites!
You can talk to each bear every day for a quest - sometimes it's story related, other times it's just a temporary "thing to do" kind of quest. Those temporary quests are timed, but don't panic! It just means they clear away the next day, and you don't lose anything by not doing them. There are also guests who show up on specific days, and a few built-in seasonal events, and furniture items that show up in a random order each time you play!

This game told me to take it slow and I took that to heart. I got overwhelmed with the quests, took a long break, then came back and only played as long as I was still having fun. The game never punished me for taking my time. After I returned, I developed much healthier habits - putting less pressure on myself to do *all* the quests, or get *all* the seasonal bugs and fish - and was able to enjoy more of the game as a whole!

It's well worth playing n_n | cozy grove is just what i need in a nice, cozy management game! i love the limited daily loop, it really makes me feel like there's no pressure to get everything done in one sitting. great game to play between classes or when i'm sick, like right now lol, definitely worth a buy! | Meh. The daily grind and unchangeable villagers are a pain. You have to feed and harvest animals of each tier 500 times, and animals donâ€™t want to be fed everyday. You have to mend 200 broken heart imps for the max badge. Thatâ€™s 200 days of gameplay [i]AND[/i] thatâ€™s if you can get [b]BOTH[/b] imps to spawn. Iâ€™ve constantly been victim to single heartbroken imps spawning, so I canâ€™t even complete that badge within 200 days. On top of that, you need 30 birds, 30 deer, 20 â€œbunniesâ€, 150 decorations, 150 flowers, and 100 fruit trees to finish the decoration badges collection. Do you want to know what thatâ€™s like? I have to hoard the floral and fauna and Iâ€™ve had the Unity crash screen when I decide to perform one too many actions with all of this junk on the screen. [h3]Great idle game, but abandoned?[/h3]  

This is a really well-designed idle game with a lot of potential. However, the game remains incomplete, and the last update was in July 2023.

I understand that life can bring challenges, but game development, especially when money is involved, is still a business. And with any business comes responsibility. Many other idle games have faced similar struggles, yet their developers found ways to keep the games progressing, whether through direct development, collaboration, or passing the project to someone else. Unfortunately, this developer seems to have taken a completely passive approach, leaving the game in limbo.

If you're considering buying this, be aware that what you see is likely all you'll get. | The game is a prototype, not even an early access. And it has been like that for several years already.
Don't play it, it is empty and unfun. There are better idle games out there. | About the first three to four chapters were *chef smooch for this genre. By Chapter 6, the slog had begun in earnest. I gassed out ultimately at Chapter 9. This really feels like a game that didn't know when to quit.
Sigh... I think I still have to recommend it because even the first four chapters were worth the price of admission. | I suppose I should get around to leaving a review for this game since I have almost 600 hours in it. It's more than worth the price if you enjoy games that make numbers go up, whether that's idle games, roguelites, or rpgs. Buy this and enjoy. | This game falls into the pitfall of many idlers where the grind is the entire gameplay. I tried to enjoy it, I really did, but it quickly got to the point where progress was literally impossible without grinding out several more lives to shave off seconds. The brutal time limit created by the ramping health decay was an interesting idea, but it failed to add more enjoyment to the game in its current form. Unless you move fast enough (by painfully slogging through the entire game to get to NG+ or by bashing your head against the time wall for hours on end) you WILL get to a point where your skills are just *too low* to keep up with the exponentially faster demand of food, once again DEMANDING that you restart from the very beginning and *slog* your way through the very beginning *again*.

I have too many other things that I would rather spend my time with, and I need to manage my REAL time carefully. Playing an idler where the main gameplay loop is waiting for a timer to go up out of nothing but *spite*? Not worth my time.

It also doesn't help that it's padding all the way down, I swear this game ends 3 times and there are entire classic Mario and Sonic levels you could finish before beating some of the end game enemy encounters. Overall a good game, but there are positives and negatives.
Pros:
+ Lots of varied strategies and synergies to choose from
+ Game rewards you for strategic thinking and considering many angles. 
+ Satisfyingly difficult without feeling unfair
Cons:
- The voice acting, lore, and overall visual presentation is bland
- Synergies matter more than individual units in most cases. Your opponent's strategy doesn't matter either.
- Replay value isn't forever since playing the same builds get boring after a while | Great game, very mellow to play casually. laidback game with no time pressure to accomplish tasks or complete quests. very cute art and 2D graphics makes gameplay not feel overstimulating. kind of like a cross between animal crossing and pokemon (never played stardew but would assume it is similar to that too) | Discovered this delightful game last year, and it became my favourite game I played in 2024!
Farming-sim-lite gameplay that compliments a fun creature collector/deckbuilding game, Moonstone Island is a perfect blend of cute, relaxing and fun. While the farming elements - something I usually gravitate to in a game - are very simple, they tie in spectacularly with the battle system and get you growing some crops for profit and others to use strategically in fights. The NPCs are simple but interesting and fostering your relationship and going on dates feels rewarding. The artstyle is some of my favourite I've seen in a farming sim, cute and cheerful and beautifully animated, and the OST is superb ("Shuffling Around" is my favourite!). After almost 200 hours I've experienced no bugs or crashes on PC.
An absolute blast of a game with addictive creature collection, fun and versatile battle mechanics, relaxing pace and a simple but satisfying story. 9/10, and one of my favourite games in a while :) | After a month of playing all saved data was lost. I played for 70 hours and I enjoyed it, and I have beaten this game on its hardest difficulty level.  So I think I can write a short review.

This is a roguelike cardgame.  Slay the Spire is the most famous of this type of game.

This game is probably something like 2nd place for roguelike cardgames, and that is pretty high praise.

That's the TLDR, here are some misc details you may find intersting:

*  This game puts pressure on you from the first fight.  It's not a game where there are a bunch of easy fights, and then a hard boss.  Every fight can kill you.  

*  At the beginning of each run, you draft a leader, one of three from huge pool that you never have complete access to.  Most of these leaders are not really very viable though.   Choose carfully!

*  There are 3 different teams to play as.  One is the sort of "generic" team, but it can specialize in ice, poison, or healing, among a few other minor things.    One is the "summoner" team and summoning is very strong because, you can tank with the summed characters.  One is the "gnome" team which uses gadgets and ink.  The ink is very strong because it cancels the enemy's special ability.

 | This is hard to recommend because visually it's fantastic. They nailed every artistic aspect of this game to a T, genuinely beautiful.

Wanted to get that out of the way since, as a deckbuilder, it's severely lacking, and has critical problems, major one being the difficulty. Because the way the game is designed, every encounter can end up being extremely lethal, and there can be a lot of "checkmate" scenarios depending on whether you got crowns, got a poor opener, or have your build counter-picked by a random pack of stage 2 enemies. 

"Oh git gud!" the content creator that gets paid to play these games bellows! But once you do "git gud" it just showcases more issues, and digs into the game's 2nd biggest problem; the variety.

Some keywords are much better than others (barrage, multiple frenzy stacks), and your ideal strategy is basically a game of kingmaker where you build up 1 insanely oppressive unit and either spend resources to keep his permanence, or buff him further to hyper carry you through fights before they can get in a scratch. And nearly every "good" deck plays like this. Diverging into alternate wincons usually leads to a loss, and rather than trying out cool and unique interactions, you're basically taking mediocre or even bad units just as a meat shield. 

And every class aims for these same deck outlines too, reducing synergy. It's like if you have a Warrior Mage Rogue trifecta, but the most optimal way of building all 3 classes is to stack as much strength as possible, including on the Mage, and really once you figure that out it just turns into a frustrating back and forth similar to Balatro, where you're just fishing in the first stage of the game for a good opener to build your deck around. And mind you, all these issues exist on base ascension (difficulty) so the game has its difficulty frontloaded, doubly so once you realize 90% of builds and cards are terrible.

 It's really annoying coming back and forth to such a lovely looking game, being stuck with a terrible and more linear experience than just about every single other deckbuilding alternative existing on here. Try out out when it's on sale, maybe you'll like it more than I did. | Great game, I loved it - beautiful artwork, unique setting, fun game play with a unique touch to the rogue-like deck builder genre. I played it at release which I thoroughly enjoyed with some different cards and higher difficulty, and end of last year with re balancing and more content.

Even though it has less depth and variety in the genre, the mechanics feel really well. It can be hard to force a certain build, but once star aligned you feel like you're unstoppable. Still, if you don't pay attention, or think the turn through, you can still get your ass whopped. The art direction and setting give a more cutesy-happy upbeat vibe which is not only done well, but gives it a more fresh look within the genre. 

TLDR:
- Upbeat comfy art direction unique to its genre
- A slightly different take on the deckbuilder roguelike genre
- Difficult from the start - leaving a lot of opportunity to mess up. If you start playing it, don't give up on the first few hours, it'll get better and more rewarding over time.
- Rewarding and great feeling when it is the run and plays out as you planned for
- A little less variety (cards and items) and repeatability like other games within the genre. This could be a specific decision by the devs to see similar cards & items appear more often. It still offers daily challenge runs, which I personally did not use as much, but I can see the appeal for others. 

It is a high-recommended on my list if you like strategy roguelikes like Slay the Spire & Peglin, and hope to see more games like this. | Pleasantly surprised after trying crappy StS copiers over and over, regularly being disappointed.

Art is about perfect as long as cuteness doesn't bother you. They really killed it with the art and frankly I'm jealous. The style looks complicated and simple at the same time, yet still manages to have flavor that stands out. It's a great commitment to a just-right amount of detail. Each character obviously took a lot of work. Even the card design looks special, with its raised pieces and lighthearted creatures. The music has similar effect on how much it aids the game.

The gameplay's reasonably unique and avoids the mana per turn trope essentially all card games run with. Instead each card played brings every character 1 closer to attacking and using innate abilities. Each character has different timers which can be messed with. Also a 2x3 battlefield for friendly heroes. As far as depth, games like SlayTheSpire or Roguebook have more going on. But you're still going to lose sometimes as you climb up the ascension, and it's more than enough to keep you thinking for a bit about refining your deck and taking turns correctly.


A few problems:

- Animations and transitions are overly slow and waste a lot of time even if they look good.

Enemy variety is lacking. Runs still feel decently different due to deck archetypes, but overall there are probably not enough fun variables between runs.

- Card readability could be better. It's not bad, but hp/atk don't stand out enough for interpretation of the field at a glance. I can see they probably wanted to avoid going too far and making the cards less attractive.

- Grind gated grinding. You get no credit towards unlocks (cards/items/etc) before the current grind is completed. So you have to start grinds from 0 that you should have already earned. It's just adding a grind requirement before we're allowed to play the full game, and making it even more annoying than it has to. Life is short and this is a gross business practice that gets people addicted and stretches out content. Gaming is sad sometimes. Yes it's satisfying to unlock stuff, but it's obviously exploitative and wastes precious time.

- Last boss/new runs mechanics SLIGHT SPOILERS: [spoiler] You fight your previous winning deck/leader each new game. Very cool, but makes next runs harder the more cohesive your team was with no way to reset it. It makes you feel bad for playing well and having a crazy deck going, or picking up that one extra accessory. I applaud the bravery of this mechanic and enjoy it... while also being annoyed by its direct contradiction to the goal of making the best deck/leader possible. [/spoiler]

Absolutely worth my time, even if it seems to have less long-term stay than StS; no surprise. Great game. | Je l'adore, mais aprÃ¨s avoir terminÃ© 2 runs, je ne parviens JAMAIS a terminer le boss final...

This was a really calming & fun game to play. The puzzles on normal mode were relatively straight-forward and easy and took 3-5 minutes on average to complete. Recommended, especially on discount.

Gute Idee ! Sehr abwechslungsreich. | [h3]Pretty chill deck building based on resource and space management, but it does require a certain amount of grind and can get repetitive.[/h3]

This is your game if you want a deck building that doesn't involve (constant) combats, or if you find some city builders too complex: here each card is usually a building and you just need to pay its cost and place it next to the resorces it harvests. Yeah, once in a while one or two enemies will show up and you need a couple of warrior or divine power cards to defend yourself, but for the most part it's a pretty chill game.

The bad news is that there are only 4 different civilizations you can play with, and each has a pretty clear "best strategy", so once you play once or twice with each one it can get repetitive pretty quickly (all games will feel the same). The worst part is that you need to play a good number of very similar games to complete the campaign or unlock the best cards, so it can become a chore.

I would recommend this game if you find it on sale for $ 10 / â‚¬ 10 or less, the first 10-15 hours of gameplay are pretty fun.

A good pack, but not as great as the rest.

Out of all the games in the entire history of Jackbox, Fibbage was not the game that needed another installment. That being said, Fibbage is still fun. This one just has updated prompts (2019 to 2022) and a new special round where you watch old movies and then lie about them. The Enough About You mode also returns, but without the second round. Totally fine addition, but a bit confusing.

Roomerang is the classic "write funny stuff into prompts" with the twist of added roleplaying. Main issues here only pop up depending on the type of players you are playing with. People who just dont wanna roleplay will just answer the prompts normally, and the game cant punish that. It is pretty good if you find some willing people to play.

Junktopia is sorta like 5's Patently Stupid, but instead of drawing your things to sell to other players, you buy them from a store. If you liked Patently, you will most likely enjoy this.

Nonsensory is a "drawing" title for the pack, but also the other writing game. You need to write/draw something on a scale of 1 to 10, but you are given a number to aim. Other players then guess what your number was. This is great, however due to the black background and green drawing lines in the actual game versus the white background with black drawing on your phone, your drawings can get mangled after submission. Be careful.

Quixort is a trivia game where you sort falling blocks. This is done in teams. The particular problem here is that a single round is quite long, since one team has to sort, then the other team sorts, meanwhile the team who sorted first has literally nothing to do for up to 20 minutes. This is also amplified in the final round, where you have to sort the same thing TWICE. However, if you have something to do for the dormant players, this issue completely disappears.

To sum up, Party Pack 9 is a good pack, even great at times, but suffers from the somewhat unavoidable "how do i make this unique" problem, which you get after 9 parts of anything, really.

It's worth picking up, but if you are looking for a Party Pack to start with, buy 7, 5 or 8 instead. | idc how fun it is i havent played it this shit should not be 9 gigabytes | Really nice game. We had a lot of fun. | Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¸Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞµ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ»Ğµ Ğ²Ñ‹Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ° Ñ€ĞµĞ¶Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ°

I never played these games back when they were first on mobile, however they still give such an odd amount of nostalgia. I've been playing through this company's games and they are addictive. Adorable art and sound effects, plus it's chill and easy to get all the achievements too. I think it's worth the price if you like casual games! | Lo jugue sin esperar mucho ya que no habia jugado nada de este desarrollador y me quede enganchado jugando por varias horas xd

Neutral review.
The game is *supposed* to be not very clear on what to do next, to make you explore - but that ended up being very frustrating for me as I just wanted to do all the quests and see what was supposed to happen next.
The day cycle was also very short and made me a little put off by how many times we had to repeat ourselves.
The graphics are adorable and the story is adorable, I'm literally just waiting for a guide so I can actually play it without feeling like I wasn't getting anything done.
Highly recommend for multiplayer, its WAY harder alone as you get to do half the things.

Too easy with silly things very time consuming. Most of the time I just try to figure it out, after very easy....

I have finished the game in 13 hours! I expected more replayability (and more strategy)

It is satisfying, but having to wait for random parts that clutter your world, and not having nearly enough ground pieces, while selling back a piece can make you not see it in some time wakes up the worst of hoarding in me. It is therefore not relaxing, but rather a battle of being able to fit everything on the random ground pieces. There should maybe be an intventory system, so that you can store things, except just the boxes and chests, so that you do not have to remove everything to even sort the ground pieces. If there was an inventory or a sandbox mode with full access to the items in the game, i would 100% give it recommended, but this just is waay to stressfull for a relaxing game. 

The music and design is also great, and my only gripe is just the amount of clutter my brain has to go through. | This is extremely addicting, dont think you can multitask with this on the side because this will suck in ALL of your attention.

Itâ€™s the perfect game for anyone who loves idle games, organizing, or collecting. This cozy sandbox allows you to build and customize to your heartâ€™s content, and the possibilities feel endless.

What really stands out for me is the sheer amount of items available. There are tons to choose from, and itâ€™s so fun to mix and match to create the perfect scene. Plus, the seasonal items (like for winter and autumn) are a lovely touch, and I adore the different color variants some items come in! 

The ability to change your background and add extra elements like falling leaves or sparkling stars adds another layer of charm and customization. Itâ€™s a game that lets you express yourself, whether you're designing a cozy garden or building an intricate little world.

If you're into games that let you relax and create without pressure, Garden Galaxy is definitely worth checking out. It's a peaceful escape into a world full of possibilities, and I can't recommend it enough!

Best 1 GBP ever invested. Lots of hours of great fun, especially if your favourite part of Stardew Valley is maximizing profits and efficiency. Careful though, it's really addictive and very easy to get absorbed by it. 
 | Another Farm Roguelike blends farming sims and roguelikes into a unique concept resulting in a challenging but cosy strategic farming experience under daily deadlines. However, it lacks a tutorial, leaving players stuck and reliant on external guides. Worse, it feels abandoned in favour of a money-grabby sequel, showing zero commitment to finishing the first game. With great potential but rough execution, I wouldnâ€™t recommend buying it.

I loved this chill yet frantic farming game. It will last you a couple fun hours and I love the theme and light take on automation. | ê°œê¸°ì—¬ìš´ ë†ì¥ ê²Œì„ ë©ë•Œë¦¬ê³  ë©˜íƒˆ ë³µêµ¬í•˜ê¸° ì¢‹ìŒ

An absolute gem, if you like Stardew Valley, but don't like how "big" it is, this game is for you. It is perfect in every way. The characters are designed wonderfully and they are so cute. I usually spam through dialogue in these types of games because the NPC's usually say the same thing over and over again, however, the characters all have something new to say. It makes the game refreshing and not tedious when it comes to getting the characters friendship level up. It makes the game more interesting and so lively. The little quirks the characters have are so well played in the dialogue and everyone in the town says something about one  another. This game does not feel like I'm playing a game, it actually feels like I'm interacting with real people, that sounds weird, but these characters are so different from each other and have different quirks and cute details to them. This game is so cute and I can't wait for future updates.

I also cannot wait for the marriage update, that's what I am most looking forward to. | ç±³æ–¯ç‰¹é‡Œäºšç‰§åœºå·²ç»æ”¶è·äº†è¶³å¤Ÿå¤šçš„å¥½è¯„æ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘è¦è®°å½•ä¸€ä¸‹å®é™…æ¸¸ç©ä¸‹æ¥æ„Ÿè§‰å¾ˆéš¾å—çš„ç‚¹

Game Name: Card Survival: Tropical Island - The First Days
Reviews: No Reviews

Pretty cool. Engaging gameplay. Good card and artifact mechanics that let you build incredibly powerful synergies. Really adorable characters and writing. Easy recommend.

Something I'm not entirely on board with is the pacing though. Usually you deckbuilders are stacked toward making it really hard to complete a run. You need to unlock things and have some luck on your side to get an amazing run. Here the runs are actually pretty easy. You're likely to win every time on Normal. The trick is you need to complete the game multiple times to unlock stuff and progress story. ç»¼ä¸Šï¼ŒåŸä»·è´­å…¥ç•¥æ˜¾ä¸å€¼ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å¦‚æœèƒ½ä»¥ä¸€ä¸ªåˆç†çš„ä»·æ ¼å…¥æ‰‹ï¼Œè¯·åŠ¡å¿…ä½“éªŒä¸€ä¸‹è¿™æ¬¾æ¸¸æˆ | "Unique Mechanics and Memorable Characters."

Cobalt Core carves out its own niche in the roguelike genre with a fresh approach to gameplay and mechanics. Itâ€™s a game that emphasizes strategic ship movement and the precise use of cards, creating tense and rewarding encounters that set it apart from the crowd.

The core gameplay shines with its focus on positioning and timing. Each move feels meaningful, and the balance between ship maneuvering and card usage adds a layer of strategy that keeps every run engaging. The length of each run is just right, avoiding the fatigue of overly long sessions while still offering a satisfying sense of progression.

One of the standout features is the lighthearted and charming cast of characters. Their short, meaningful conversations drive the story forward without bogging down the paceâ€”a perfect fit for a roguelike game. The narrative elements provide just enough depth to make you care about the world and its inhabitants while keeping the focus on gameplay.

Visually, Cobalt Core is a treat. The 2D pixel art style is beautifully crafted, with vibrant colors and detailed designs that enhance the overall experience. The audio complements the visuals well, with a solid soundtrack and sound effects that add to the atmosphere without overwhelming the player.

While the gameâ€™s design is top-tier, its one notable flaw is the requirement to repeat runs to unlock additional content. This repetition can feel a bit tedious at times, especially for players who prefer more variety in their progression. However, the engaging mechanics and overall quality of the game help mitigate this issue.

Cobalt Core is a standout entry in the roguelike card game genre, offering a unique blend of strategy, charm, and polish. Its innovative mechanics, memorable characters, and beautiful presentation make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Despite some minor repetition, the gameâ€™s overall design and execution are top-notch, delivering an experience thatâ€™s as enjoyable as it is rewarding. | I played this game a few times and didn't understand how to play. I kept dying. But then I figured out that movement points don't need to be spent that turn. You can click on a movement card and save the movement points for a different turn. Game became much easier once I figured that out. 

And now I understand why it's one of the highest rated games on Steam. Lots of fun. | I Loved FTL back in the day, played a few rougelikes that scratched that itch since then, Crying Suns was the best for the Space ship thing but gameplay was certainly different,I  loved the setting/story. Recently Peglin really got it's hooks in me with the deck (ball) building. 
Cobalt Core's feels like the perfect mix of FTL's ship gameplay (though different), Peglin's Deck building type upgrade (but actually cards), and Crying Suns setting/story (but make it cute instead of oppressing grim dark). 
It's really got me and really scratches that FTL itch!

And Riggs is the best by the way...

With the latest update, the terms of service now include a section where they can, without notifying you, disclose your personal information (IP address, personal information, chat logs, payment information and other information) to third parties. 

When I tried to opt out of this, I got redirected to a page which informs you "The Warner Bros. Discovery Privacy Center is Not Available in Your Region."

I've sunk 80+ hours of time into this game, which is now being held hostage unless I agree to give them my person information. Very disappointing.


For reference here's the relevant section, straight from their terms of service:
"You understand that WB Games may, with or without notice to you, disclose your Internet Protocol (IP) address(es), personal information, chat logs, payment information and other information about you and your activities to third parties, in response to a request by law enforcement, a court order or other legal process, or if WB Games believes that doing so may protect your safety or the safety of others. If you are a user outside the United States, you also consent to the transfer of your data to the United States." | This review is a little biased because this is the first Harry Potter universe game Iâ€™ve fully completed and gotten 100% achievements in.  

First of all, Iâ€™m so glad this isnâ€™t another game where you just play as Harry Potter. Instead, you get to create your own character and fully experience the world of Hogwarts. That alone made it worth playing for me.  

 [h2]Gameplay[/h2]
The developers clearly put a lot of love into this game, and it shows. [b]Hogwarts Castle[/b] is absolutely stunning so much so that it actually made me tear up at times. Everything feels alive, from NPCs casually using magic to paint pictures or prank each other to weird potion experiments happening in the bathrooms. I could spend hours just listening to NPC conversations.  

The game has three main areas:  
- [b]Hogwarts Castle[/b] â€“ Easily the best part of the game, full of detail, personality, and magic everywhere.  
- [b]Hogsmeade[/b] â€“ A charming, lively village thatâ€™s fun to explore and next to the castle.
- [b]The Open World[/b] â€“ This was hit-or-miss for me. It has some interesting moments, but compared to Hogwarts, it feels less polished and emptier. It honestly felt like two different teams worked on these areasâ€”the castle is [b]bursting with life[/b], while the open world feels [b]weaker in quality[/b]. Most collectibles and side quests take place in the open world, which was fine, but I personally wouldâ€™ve loved more focus on the castle itself.  

That said, side missions were actually fun and never felt like a chore. The Forbidden Forest, while well-designed, didnâ€™t feel as scary as I imagined it would be.  
This game also has [b]a ton[/b] of collectibles and optional content for 100% completion. Unfortunately, three of the achievements require replaying the game three times up to a certain point, which felt like a grind and should honestly be removed.  
Spiders. Spiders everywhere. Every five minutes, the game throws you into another cave full of horrifying spiders. Thankfully, the devs included an [b]Arachnophobia Mode[/b] for those who canâ€™t handle them.  

[h2]Combat[/h2]
Iâ€™m absolutely in love with the combat. Itâ€™s even better on Hard difficulty, but Normal strikes a great balance between fun and challenge. Honestly, this game has ruined traditional mage/wizard combat for me nothing else feels as good after playing this. The spell combos, dodging, and enemy variety make every fight feel pretty dynamic.  
Although opinions on this are mixed, I personally really vibed with it.

[h2] Story[/h2]
The story was [b]okay[/b] nothing special. Itâ€™s your typical "kill the bad guy to save the world" kind of plot. The side quests and relationship quests were way more engaging than the main story, and I actually found myself more invested in those.  

[h2]âŒ Cons[/h2]

- [b]Major Lighting Issues in Interior Areas [/b] :
(As of new update on January 30th 2025)
Many caves and rooms are blindingly bright, like a flashbang directly to the eyesâ€”completely white screens that are painful to look at. If you have epilepsy, be careful. This is a weird bug since these areas are fully enclosed with no sunlight source, but the moment you step into certain spots, itâ€™s like staring directly into the sun.

- [b]Performance Issues[/b] : 
Iâ€™m running this game on an RTX 4060 at 1440p, and while it looks great, it has some serious issues:  

[b]Texture Pop-in / Loading Issues[/b] â€“ My biggest complaint. This is a well-known PC bug that happens even on the lowest settings. NPCs, grass, and objects suddenly pop into existence right in front of you, completely ruining immersion. Whatâ€™s frustrating is that the game used to run way better at launch, but the last update (around six months ago) broke a lot of things, and they never fixed it.  
Some examples of texture pop-in issues:  
- NPCs suddenly appearing a few steps away when I turn the camera.  
- Half-invisible cows in Hogsmeade.  
- Grass abruptly loading every time the camera angle changes during a conversation or cutscene.  
- Even opening the menu and returning to the game makes textures freak out.  
>[b]Edit[/b] : As of the new update on 30th January texture pop in issues is mostly fixed, its still here and there but nothing immersion breaking.

[b]Ray Tracing is a Mess[/b] â€“ Turning on RT causes micro-stutters and makes texture pop-in even worse. Itâ€™s simply not worth using in this game currently, it used to be way better before.
>[b]Edit[/b] : As of the new update on 30th January, they added ray reconstruction, DLSS 4 to this game. RT performance is a bit better but its still a mess in open world areas.

[b]Winter Season FPS Drops[/b] â€“ For some reason, when it snows, my FPS gets cut in half. Itâ€™s a massive bummer because winter in Hogwarts should feel magical, but instead, it just lags.  (I have not checked this in the new update)

- [b]Low Replayability[/b] â€“ While each house has an exclusive quest, replaying the whole game just for one extra mission isnâ€™t very appealing. However, the upcoming PC modding update should help with this issue.  I'm honestly depressed this game is over I want to experience it more :(
>[b]Edit[/b] : New mod update did not help with this but there's rumours about them adding possible new story content to the game, nothing concrete tho.

If they ever fix these issues, this game would be so much more enjoyable.  

[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]
I just want to thank the devs for creating such an amazing game. It was one of the best gaming experiences Iâ€™ve had. Despite its flaws, I still highly recommend it.
